    Every grant of a franchise shall specify its duration, terms, fees, compensation, conditions, record keeping and other provisions and requirements as reasonably determined by City Council. 
Section 15.4. - Revocable Permits or Licenses. 
    The City may grant a permit or license at any time for the temporary use or occupation of any street, alley, other public way, or City-owned place. Any such permit or license shall be revocable by the City at any time and without cause, whether or not such right to revoke is expressly reserved in the permit, license or agreement. 
ARTICLE 16. - IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS 
    The Council, subject to applicable legal restrictions and/or requirements, shall have authority to create, by ordinance, improvement districts within the City. 
ARTICLE 17. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 

Section 17.1. - Existing Boards and Commissions. 
    Each board and commission existing at the time this Charter is adopted shall continue, except as otherwise provided by ordinance. The City Council may, by ordinance, establish, consolidate or abolish any board or commission. 
Section 17.2. - Boards and Commissions-General. 
A.  The Council may, by ordinance, provide that boards and commissions shall be advisory in character. The selection, term, responsibilities and policies concerning each board and commission shall be as established by ordinance. 
B.  The appointment or removal of any board or commission member who is required by ordinance to be appointed by the City Council shall require the affirmative vote of a majority of the entire Council. A member appointed by the City Council shall serve at the pleasure of Council. 
ARTICLE 18. - GENERAL LEGAL PROVISIONS 

Section 18.1. - Interpretation. 
A.  Except as otherwise specifically provided in or indicated by the context, all words used in this Charter indicating the present tense shall not be limited to the time of the adoption of this Charter, but shall extend to and include the time of the happening of any event or requirement for which provision is made in this Charter. 
B.  Except as otherwise specifically provided in or indicated by the context, the singular number shall include the plural, the plural shall include the singular, and the word "person" may extend and be applied to bodies politic and corporate, partnerships, individuals and other public or private entities. 
Section 18.2. - Severability of Charter Provisions. 
    If any part of this Charter or the application of any part of this Charter to any person or circumstance is found to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the validity of any remaining part of this Charter, and to this end this Charter is declared to be severable. 
Section 18.3. - Bonding. 
    Before permitting any City official or employee to perform any function or duty involving the handling of City funds, the Council shall require, by ordinance, that such person shall obtain a fidelity bond or insurance coverage in an amount prescribed by Council, the cost of which shall be paid by the City. 
Section 18.4. - Bequests, Gifts and Donations. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this Charter, the City may receive bequests, gifts, and donations of all kinds of property with power to manage, sell, lease, or otherwise dispose or provide for the disposition of same. 
Section 18.5. - Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays. 
    If the last day of any period required to be computed under this Charter is a Saturday, Sunday, City, state or national holiday, the period shall be extended to include the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or holiday. 
Section 18.6. - Penalty for Violation of Charter. 
    Any willful violation of a provision of this Charter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and may be prosecuted in the Municipal Court. Any person convicted of such a violation may be punished by imprisonment for a term not to exceed the maximum term of imprisonment that the Municipal Court is authorized to impose, by a fine in an amount not to exceed the maximum fine that the Municipal Court is authorized to impose, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
Section 18.7. - Intergovernmental Agreements. 
    The Council may, by resolution or by ordinance, enter into contracts or agreements with public and/or governmental units, agencies, boards and commissions, persons and entities for the use of properties, improvements, buildings, equipment, or facilities, and for furnishing or receiving commodities or services and for all other legal purposes. 
Section 18.8. - Competitive Bidding. 
    Purchases of or contracts for supplies, services, materials, equipment or improvements shall be made under such requirements regarding competitive bidding as shall be prescribed by ordinance. 
Section 18.9. - Emergency Acquisitions. 
    In case of an emergency affecting the public peace, well-being, health, or safety, the Council may waive all provisions for competitive bidding and direct the City Manager, acting as purchasing agent for the City, to purchase, use, acquire and/or lease equipment, goods, supplies, services and materials. 
ARTICLE 19. - TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS 

Section 19.1. - Effective Date of Charter. 
    This Charter shall become effective immediately upon filing and recording with the Secretary of State of Colorado following approval of the registered electors of the City. 
Section 19.2. - Prior City Legislation. 
    All ordinances, resolutions, rules, regulations, policies and procedures of the City which are not inconsistent with this Charter and which are in full force and effect on the effective date of this Charter shall continue in full force and effect until repealed or amended. Any provision of any ordinances, resolutions, rules or regulations, policies and procedures which are inconsistent with this Charter is hereby repealed. 
Section 19.3. - Continuation of Appointed Officers and Employees. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, after the effective date of this Charter, all appointed officers and all employees of the City shall continue in that City office or employment, which corresponds to the City office or employment which they held prior to the effective date of this Charter as though they had been appointed or employed in the manner provided in this Charter. They shall, in all respects, be subject to the provisions of this Charter, except that any officer or employee who holds a position which this Charter provides be held at the pleasure of the appointing officer or body, shall hold such position only at such pleasure regardless of the term for which originally appointed. 
Section 19.4. - Continuation of Terms of Office-Mayor, Councilmembers, City Clerk, City Treasurer and Board and Commission Members. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this Charter, the terms of office of the Mayor, each Councilmember, the City Clerk, the City Treasurer and of the members of each City board and commission, serving prior to the effective date of this Charter, shall continue. 
Section 19.5. - Saving Clause. 
    Neither the adoption of this Charter nor the amendment or repeal of any ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation, policy or procedure, or portion thereof, inconsistent with this Charter, shall be construed to destroy any property right, contract right or right of action of any nature or kind, civil or criminal, vested in or against the City by virtue of any such ordinance, resolution, rule, or regulation, policy or procedure, or portion thereof, or any other provision of law theretofore existing or otherwise accruing to the City. All such rights shall vest in and inure to the City or to any persons asserting any such claims against the City as fully and as completely as though this Charter had not been adopted and as though there had been no amendment or repeal of any ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation, policy, contract or procedure, or portion thereof. Such rights shall include but not be limited to: 
a.  Any contractual relationships between the City and any employee by virtue of any retirement and pension plans in effect on the effective date of this Charter; and 
b.  Any franchise ordinances and agreements of the City in effect on the effective date of this Charter; and 
c.  Any contracts between the City and any person, company, individual, entity, government or corporation. 
ARTICLE 20. - DEFINITIONS 
    The following definitions shall apply as used in this Charter: 
1.  "Abuse of public office" means any violation of State statutes relating to public trust or public funds classified as a felony or a misdemeanor, and any violation described in State statutes which is classified as a felony. 
2.  "Ad valorem tax" means only the general property tax levied annually on taxable real or personal property listed with the assessor of Arapahoe County, Colorado. 
3.  "Appropriation" means the authorized amount of monetary funds designated for an expenditure during a specified time for a specified purpose, usually as an appropriation of funds in the City budget or amendment thereto. 
4.  "Board or Commission" or "Board and Commission" means the boards and commissions established by this Charter or ordinances. 
5.  "City" means the City of Sheridan, Colorado. 
6.  "Clerk" means the City Clerk of the City of Sheridan or such office designation as may be used in place of the office of City Clerk. 
7.  "Collaboratively" means working together. 
8.  "Council" or "City Council" means the governing body constituting the City Council of the City, including the Mayor. 
9.  "Councilmember" means each member of the City Council, except the Mayor. 
10.  "Descriptive title" means that the title of an ordinance shall contain a reasonable description of the contents of the ordinance. 
11.  "Elected Official" means the Mayor and each Councilmember, whether elected or appointed. 
12.  "Emergency ordinance" means an ordinance which, in the opinion of the City Council is necessary for the immediate preservation of the public property, health, welfare, peace or safety. 
13.  "Employee" means each compensated person in the service of the City who is designated as an employee in the personnel code or applicable rules and regulations of the City. 
14.  "Entire Council" means all of the members of the Council, including the Mayor, provided for in Article 2. 
15.  "Franchise" means a right conferred by the City (such as to a public utility) to use public property for public use but for private profit. 
16.  "General applicability" means those ordinances which apply to the City as a whole, such as by illustration only, traffic control laws, general offenses, zoning classifications and building codes. It does not apply to ordinances such as by illustration only, zoning or rezoning of specific parcels of land, annexation of specific properties and employee pay plans. 
17.  "General election" or "Statewide general election" means the statewide election held on the Tuesday succeeding the first Monday of November in each even-numbered year. 
18.  "In-camera" means in the judge's private chambers or in the courtroom with all spectators and public excluded. 
19.  "Initiative" means the power of the registered electors of the City of Sheridan to propose to City Council, in accordance with the provisions of this Charter, certain ordinances for adoption by City Council which, if not adopted by Council, shall be submitted to a vote of the registered electors of the City for acceptance or rejection, in accordance with the provisions of this Charter. 
20.  "Manager" means the City Manager of the City of Sheridan appointed by City Council. 
21.  "Mayor" means the Mayor of the City. 
22.  "Newspaper" means a newspaper of general circulation in the City which meets the requirements for a legal newspaper as established in the State statutes. 
23.  "Notice" means that notice may be provided to the public as prescribed by this Charter and/or by ordinance by all means and methods of communication. 
24.  "Officer" means the Mayor and each Councilmember. 
25.  "Ordinance" means a permanent law or regulation adopted by legislative action of the City Council pursuant to the procedures set forth in this Charter or by ordinances. 
26.  "Publication or Posting" means: 
A.  Publication in a newspaper of general circulation; or 
B.  Publication by electronic means and methods; or 
C.  In the event of an emergency, or when no such newspaper is available, posting. Anything published by such posting because of an emergency shall subsequently be published in a newspaper of general circulation or published electronically; or 
D.  Posting shall be effected by providing written or printed notice in various locations throughout the City as provided by ordinance. 
27.  "Referendum" means the power of the registered electors of the City of Sheridan to request that City Council reconsider certain ordinances adopted by the Council as provided in this Charter; and, if Council fails to repeal such ordinances, to require that Council submit the referred ordinances to a vote of the registered electors of the City for approval or rejection, in accordance with the provisions of this Charter. 
28.  "Registered Elector" means an elector who has registered in compliance with the provisions for registration to vote as provided in the State statutes. 
29.  "Regular Election" or "Regular Municipal Election" means a City election held pursuant to Article 5. 
30.  "Resolution" means an expression of an administrative or a ministerial act of Council without any required form or procedure, as distinguished from legislative acts embodied in City ordinances. 
31.  "Special Election" or "Special City Election" means a City election held at a time other than a regular election. 
32.  "State Constitution" or "Colorado Constitution" means the Constitution of the State of Colorado, as amended from time to time. 
33.  "State statutes" means the statutes of the State of Colorado, as amended or repealed from time to time and also referred to as the "Colorado Revised Statutes" or "C.R.S.". 
34.  "Treasurer" means the City Treasurer of Sheridan or such office designation as may be used in place of the office of Treasurer. 
35.  "United States Constitution" means the Constitution of the United States of America, as amended from time to time. 
CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE 
This table shows the location of the sections of the basic Charter and any amendments thereto. 
Date Section  Section 
this Charter 6- 4-2002(Elec.) Arts. 1-20 Arts. 1-20  
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Sheridan Municipal Code," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1986,  1-1) 
Charter reference- Codification,  4.8. 
State Law reference- Ordinance codification, C.R.S.  31-16-201 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council. 
    Charter. Whenever the term "Charter" is used in this Code, it shall mean and refer to the Home Rule Charter of the City of Sheridan, Colorado, as printed in Part I of this volume. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Sheridan, Colorado" followed it and shall extend to and include its officers, agents and employees. 
    City council, council. The words "city council" or "the council" shall mean the city council of Sheridan, Colorado. 
    City officials or officers. Whenever reference is made to officials, boards, commissions, departments, etc., by title only, i.e., "city clerk," "chief of police," they shall be deemed to refer to the officials, councilmembers, commissions and departments of the city. 
    Code. The term "Code" shall be deemed to mean the Sheridan Municipal Code as published and subsequently amended, unless the context requires otherwise. 
    Computation of time. In computing a period of days, the first day is excluded and the last day is included. If the last day of any period is a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the period is extended to include the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday. If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months from a particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the concluding month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun, unless there are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the period ends on the last day of that month. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Arapahoe, State of Colorado. 
    C.R.S. The abbreviation "C.R.S." shall mean the latest edition or supplement of the Colorado Revised Statutes. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears authorizing or requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the authorized or required act or make the authorized or required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designates otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships, and corporations as well as to males. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-103. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-110. 
    Legal holiday. As used in this Code, the words "legal holiday" shall include New Year's Day, Martin Luther King Day, President's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Veteran's Day, Thanksgiving Day and following Friday, Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. 
    May. The word "may" shall be construed as being permissive and not mandatory. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-106. 
    Must. The word "must" shall be construed as being mandatory. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-101. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-102. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and. The word "or" may be read as the word "and," and the word "and" may be read as the word "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Person. The word "person" shall include and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships, and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Prescribed period. Whenever a party has the right or is required to do some act or take some proceedings within a prescribed period after the service of a notice or other paper upon him, and the notice or paper is served upon him by mail, three days shall be added to the prescribed period. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-108. 
    Shall. The word "shall" shall be construed as being mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription. The words "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when a person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Colorado. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city and shall embrace all parts thereof within the designated right-of-way. 
    Tense. Words used in the present or past tense include the future as well as the present and past. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-104. 
    Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven consecutive days. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-105. 
    Written or in writing. The words "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1986,  1-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-107. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1986,  1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - References to chapters, articles or sections. 
    All references to chapters, articles or sections are to the chapters, articles and sections of this Code and all amendments or as may be amended unless otherwise specified. 
Sec. 1-5. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
Sec. 1-6. - References and editor's notes. 
    References and editor's notes following certain sections of this Code are inserted as an aid and guide to the reader and are not controlling or meant to have any legal effect. 
Sec. 1-7. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as the Sheridan Municipal Code, City of Sheridan, Colorado, and ordinances existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1986,  1-4) 
Sec. 1-8. - Code and future ordinances do not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  No offense committed, and no fine, forfeiture, or penalty incurred before the provisions of any ordinance, part of an ordinance or resolution are repealed, shall be affected, released, or in any way discharged by such repeal. But trial, conviction, and punishment for any such offense and recovery of fines, forfeitures, and penalties shall be had in all respects as if the repealed provisions had remained in force. 
(Code 1986,  1-5) 
Sec. 1-9. - Ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall repeal or affect the validity of any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising, guaranteeing or authorizing the payment of money by or for the city; 
(2)  Authorizing the issuance of bonds or other evidence of indebtedness; 
(3)  Regarding any right, contract or franchise conferred or granted by the city; 
(4)  Establishing or relating to the compensation of city officers or employees; 
(5)  Levying taxes, making appropriations or adopting a budget; 
(6)  Relating to any specific local improvement; 
(7)  Relating to any special assessment; 
(8)  Vacating, accepting, naming, establishing, locating, relocating or opening any street or public way; 
(9)  Affecting the corporate limits of the city; 
(10)  Regulating traffic or parking at specific locations, not inconsistent with this Code; 
(11)  Relating to zoning; 
(12)  Relating to subdivision; 
(13)  That is temporary, although general in effect; 
(14)  That is special, although permanent in effect; 
(15)  That was adopted for purposes that have been consummated. 
(Code 1986,  1-6) 
Sec. 1-10. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1986,  1-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-302, 2-4-303. 
Sec. 1-11. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code, which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. In the case of repealed chapters, articles, divisions sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section_______ of the Sheridan Municipal Code is hereby amended to read as follows:..." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Sheridan Municipal Code is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter)_______ to be numbered, which section reads as follows:..." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, divisions, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, division, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1986, 1-8) 
Sec. 1-12. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code, which have been repealed, shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier, meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement, may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in catchlines, headings and titles. 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _______through ______." The inserted section numbers will indicate the sections of the Code, which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code. 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-13. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1986,  1-9) 
Sec. 1-14. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever any section of this Code or any section of a rule or regulation promulgated hereunder for which the doing of any act is required, prohibited, or declared to be unlawful and no definite fine or penalty is provided for a violation thereof, any person convicted of violating such section shall for each offense, except as otherwise specified, be punished by a fine not exceeding, at the time of the commission of the offense the maximum fine established by the state for municipal ordinance violations, or imprisoned for a period of not more than one year, or by both such fine or imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  Every person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of chapter 38, motor vehicles and traffic offenses, whereupon conviction of such person is subject to the assessment of not more than four points (except for compulsory insurance) or a six point offense of speeding (not more than 24 miles over the posted speed limit) against one's driving privilege, and shall be punished by a fine only in an amount not to exceed, at the time of the commission of the offense the maximum fine established by the state for municipal ordinance violations. 
(c)  If an individual is charged with both a violation that is subject to a jury trial and one which is not and such violations arise out of the same act or transaction, such individual may have a trial by jury on all charges. 
(d)  Any child (any person under 18 years of age) convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code shall be, for each offense, fined in a sum not to exceed, at the time of the commission of the offense the maximum fine established by the state for municipal ordinance violations. The municipal judge has the authority to order a child confined in a juvenile detention facility operated or contracted by the department of institutions for failure to comply with a lawful order of the court including an order to pay a fine. Any confinement of a child for contempt shall not exceed 48 hours. 
(e)  The city shall be entitled to recover all costs and expenses including reasonable attorney fees incurred in the civil prosecution and/or litigation of any person found to have violated any section of this Code or any rule or regulation promulgated under this Code. 
(Code 1986,  1-10; Ord. No. 1-2005,  1, 1-26-2005; Ord. No. 8-2013,  1, 8-14-2013; Ord. No. 1-2016,  1, 2-8-2016 ) 
State Law reference- Penalty for violation of ordinances, C.R.S.  31-16-101. 
Sec. 1-15. - City boundaries. 
    The boundaries and corporate limits of the city shall be as indicated upon the official map thereof on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1986,  1-11) 
Sec. 1-16. - Severability. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1986,  1-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S.  2-4-204. 
Sec. 1-17. - Publication of legal documents. 
(a)  It is the legislative intent of this section to comply with the Charter's publication requirements and to provide reasonable notice to the public of the city's actions while also ensuring the timely enactment of city policies and legislation. 
(b)  The city council may, by resolution, designate a newspaper of general circulation within the city to serve as the official newspaper for publication of all city legal documents. 
(Code 1986,  1-13) 
Charter reference- Publication of ordinances,  4.6; publication defined,  20(26). 
Sec. 1-18. - Fees. 
    As provided by law, the city council shall by resolution, establish charges and fees for municipal programs, goods and services. The purpose of the charge or fee is to defray the city's costs of providing the programs, goods and services and the amount of any fee shall be reasonably related to the city's cost of rendering the particular programs, goods or services. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City seal. 
    The seal of the city shall be a seal, the impression of which shall be as follows: in the center, the words "City Seal," and around the outer edge the words "City of Sheridan, State of Colorado." 
(Code 1986,  2-1) 
State Law reference- City seal, C.R.S.  31-4-110, 31-15-101(1)(3). 
Secs. 2-2-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Term Limits, 2.5. 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for four-year terms, C.R.S.  31-4-107(3); mayor to be member of city council, C.R.S.  31-4-102(2). 

Sec. 2-21. - Election. 
    Two council members shall be elected from each of the three wards of the city. 
(Code 1986,  2-16) 
Charter reference- Elections, art. 5. 
State Law reference- Election of officers, C.R.S.  31-4-105. 
Sec. 2-22. - Rules of procedure generally. 
    The rules of procedure and order of business of the city council shall be established and made by the city council by a resolution. 
(Code 1986,  2-18) 
State Law reference- Authority of council to determine rules of procedure, C.R.S.  31-4-107(1). 
Sec. 2-23. - Meetings. 
    The city council shall hold its regular council meetings on the second and fourth Monday of each and every month, which meetings shall convene in the council chambers in the city hall or such other place as may be from time to time designated by the city council at such time as the city council may direct. 
(Code 1986,  2-19; Ord. No. 2-2014,  1, 2-26-2014 ) 
Charter reference- Meetings,  3.1. 
State Law reference- Organization meeting of council, C.R.S.  31-4-107(1). 
Sec. 2-24. - Numbering of ordinances. 
    Beginning the first day of January of each year, ordinances shall be numbered in the order of their introduction. 
(Code 1986,  2-22) 
Charter reference- Adoption Procedure for Ordinances,  4.6. 
State Law reference- Ordinance generally, C.R.S.  31-16-101 et seq. 
Sec. 2-25. - Appointment of mayor pro tem. 
(a)  The city council shall by majority vote appoint one of its members to serve as mayor pro tem who shall act as mayor when the mayor is absent or temporarily unable to perform the duties of the office. 
(b)  The initial mayor pro tem shall serve until the next general election. Thereafter the mayor pro tem shall by majority vote, be appointed at the first meeting following each general election and serve a term of two years. 
(c)  In the event of a vacancy in the office of mayor pro tem, council shall by majority vote, appoint one of its members to serve as mayor pro tem for the remainder of the vacated term. 
(Ord. No. 1-2005,  1, 1-26-2005) 
Sec. 2-26. - Abandonment of office. 
    A councilor shall be deemed to have abandoned his or her office upon the failure to attend three consecutive regular meetings, unless such absence is excused by motion of council. 
(Ord. No. 2-2012,  1, 3-14-2012) 
Secs. 2-27-2-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY MANAGER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- City manager,  7.1-7.3. 

Sec. 2-36. - Short term loan authority for city manager. 
    The city manager may obtain a short-term loan on behalf of the city where upon his/her reasonable determination, that though revenues will be shortly forthcoming, there exists an immediate need for funds to meet the city's obligations. The city manager shall immediately notify city council prior to request of the loan and any such loan must be obtained from a federally insured financial institution. Additionally, the principal amount of the loan shall not exceed $500,000.00 and the loan, including principal, interest and any penalties must be paid back in its entirety within the same fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 10-2004,  1, 5-26-2004; Ord. No. 2-2009,  1, 3-25-2009) 
Secs. 2-37-2-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Personnel manual,  7.3(a). 

Sec. 2-58. - Compensation and fringe benefits of elected officials. 
(a)  The mayor shall receive the sum of $550.00 per month as compensation for service. 
(b)  The mayor pro tem shall receive the sum of $460.00 per month as compensation for service. 
(c)  All other councilors shall receive the sum of $450.00 per month as compensation for service. 
(d)  All councilors during their term of office are entitled to receive life and accidental death and dismemberment insurance at city expense in an amount of coverage equal to the coverage provided for city employees. 
(Code 1986,  2-62; Ord. No. 2-2017,  1, 4-24-2017 ) 
Sec. 2-59. - Bond; oath. 
    No person appointed to the office of treasurer with the city shall accept such office until such person has furnished bond satisfactory to the city council. No other person shall accept an office of the city or employment with the city if he fails to file a bond when required to do so by the city council. Such bond must be satisfactory to the council. No person shall accept an office or employment with the city until such person has filed an oath of office. 
(Code 1986,  2-63) 
Secs. 2-60-2-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - POLICE AND FIRE PENSION FUND 

Secs. 2-81-2-105. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-2008,  1, adopted May 28, 2008, repealed  2-81, which pertained to the police and fire pension plan and derived from the Code of 1986,  2-101, 2-102; and Ord. No. 14-2005,  1, August 10, 2005. 
ARTICLE VI. - PROCUREMENT 

Secs. 2-106-2-126. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4-2011,  1, adopted May 11, 2011, repealed  2-106-2-126, which pertained to procurement and derived from Ord. No. 5-2004,  1(2-300), 1(2-310), 1(2-315), 1(2-320), 1(2-325), 1(2-340), 1(2-350), 1(2-355), 1(2-360), 1(2-365), 1(2-370), 1(2-375), 1(2-380), 1(3-305), 1(3-330), 1(3-335), 1(3-345), 1(3-385), 1(3-390), 1(3-395), 1(3-400), 3-24-2004. 
Sec. 2-127. - Surplus property. 
    Upon the city manager's approval that personal property is no longer necessary for city operations, obsolete or excessively expensive to maintain, such property may be: 
(1)  Sold in any manner that is open to the general public; 
(2)  Donated to a governmental or non-profit organization with a significant community service mission; 
(3)  Recycled with a reputable firm; or 
(4)  Disposed of where the property is of nominal value. 
(Ord. No. 11-2011,  1, 9-14-2011) 
Secs. 2-128-2-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - CODE OF ETHICS [4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Code of ethics,  2.4. 

Sec. 2-151. - Application. 
    The requirements set forth in this article shall be in addition to those otherwise applicable to officials, as defined herein, by the laws of the United States, State of Colorado, or otherwise contained in the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city. The more stringent standards of conduct shall prevail in the event of any conflict among the standards. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-500), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-152. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Affiliate or affiliated with means an official, employee, partner, agent, stockholder, joint venturer, or corporate director of any business organization or a person who shares office space with such organization. 
    Appear on behalf of means to act as a witness, advocate, or expert or otherwise to support the position of another person. 
    Business means a corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship, trust or foundation or any other individual or organization carrying on a business, whether or not operated for profit. 
    Confidential information means any information which is not available to the general public or deemed confidential in accordance with local, state or federal law and which is obtained by reason of an official's position or under circumstances by which a reasonable person could anticipate that such information not be disclosed. Confidential information shall also include information which, by determination of two-thirds of the entire city council, any commission, board or agency, or by determination of the city manager or city attorney, would not be in the best interests of the city if such information was made available to the public at the time it is provided to the recipient; provided, however, such determination shall be in compliance with any applicable law. Confidential information shall also include privileged attorney-client information and communication in compliance with applicable law. 
    Financial interest means a financial or monetary interest held by an individual or immediate family member, which is: 
(1)  An ownership interest in a business, including ownership of the corporate stock issued, or any other form of interest in a business; or 
(2)  A creditor interest in an insolvent business; 
(3)  An employment, or prospective employment, for which negotiations have begun; 
(4)  An ownership in real or personal property; 
(5)  A loan or other debtor interest in a business; or 
(6)  A position as director, manager or officer in a business. 
    Governing body means the members of city council, including the mayor. 
    Immediate family means a spouse, child, parent, brother, sister, or legally dependent person assuming a relationship being the substantial equivalent of those listed herein. 
    Official means: 
(1)  Any person elected or appointed to serve on city council or as the mayor. 
(2)  An appointed official means any person in the service of the city whether paid, unpaid or volunteer, including without limitation, any board, agency, committee, commission or entity of the city. 
    Official act or official action means a vote, decision, recommendation, advisory opinion, approval, disapproval, discussion or other action, including inaction, which involves the use of discretionary authority. 
    Personal interest or private interest means a benefit, advantage or right of, pertaining to, or peculiar to a certain individual. 
    Transaction means any contract, agreement, any sale or lease of any interest in land, material, supplies or services; or any granting of a development right, license, authorization, approval, permit or application. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-505), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-153. - Financial interest in a transaction. 
    Any official having the power or duty to perform an official act or action, related to a transaction which is or may be the subject of an official act or action of the city, shall abstain from any official act or action if such official: 
(1)  Has a financial interest in such transaction; or 
(2)  Has a financial interest in any business entity representing, advising, affiliated with or appearing on behalf of, whether paid or unpaid, any individual or business involved in such transaction; or 
(3)  Has solicited, accepted or granted a present or future gift, favor, service or thing of value from or to any person involved in such transaction. This prohibition against gifts shall not apply to: 
a.  An occasional, non-pecuniary gift of less than $100.00 value; 
b.  An award publicly presented in recognition of public service; 
c.  Any gift which would have been offered or given to an individual if he/she was not an official; or 
d.  Campaign contributions in full compliance with the Colorado Campaign Reform Act as amended. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-510), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-154. - Public contract. 
    No official shall participate in the making of a contract or agreement, or exercise any discretion regarding same where the official has a financial interest in such contract or agreement unless: 
(1)  The contract is awarded through a process of public notice and competitive bidding as provided in this Code or city policies, rules or regulations; or 
(2)  The city council, upon written request of such official, waives the requirements of this section after determining that it is in the best interest of the city to grant the request. 
For the purposes of this section, financial interest shall include those matters where a member of an official's immediate family has an ownership, employment, debtor or creditor relationship with the contracting party. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-515), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-155. - Legislative action. 
(a)  Any official who has a financial interest, personal interest or private interest in any matter proposed or pending before the city council, any board, commission, agency, committee or entity shall disclose such interest to the governing body of such entity and shall not vote thereon, and shall refrain from influencing or attempting to influence the decisions of the other members of such entity in voting on the matter. 
(b)  Upon disclosure of such interest, the official shall not work with or continue to work with city employees or city staff on the matter related to the conflict of interest. Such official shall not attend public meetings of the governing bodies of the entities referred to in subsection (a) above. 
(c)  An official may vote notwithstanding the existence of a conflict only if the official adheres to the procedure set forth in section 2-156. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-520), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-156. - Disclosure. 
    Any official with a financial, personal or private interest in a transaction pursuant to section 2-155 shall do the following: 
(1)  Give written notice of such interest to the city manager and the governing board of the public entity, as soon as reasonably possible after the interest has arisen. 
(2)  Refrain from voting and refrain from influencing or attempting to influence other officials regarding the matter, except that it is permissible for an official to vote if the official's participation is necessary to establish a quorum or otherwise enable the public body to act but only if written disclosure is made both to the Colorado Secretary of State pursuant to Colorado Revised Statutes, and to the public body, which shall record such disclosure and include same in its minutes. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-525), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-157. - Confidential information. 
(a)  No official with respect to any matter, which is or may be the subject of an official act or action shall, without legal authorization, disclose confidential information concerning the matter or use such information to advance the financial, personal or private interest of himself/herself or others. 
(b)  The city council or the public body may waive its privileged attorney-client communication and information regarding confidential information and matters by vote of two-thirds of the entire council or public body. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-530), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-158. - Conflict of interest; city employment. 
(a)  No official shall engage in or accept employment or render service, for financial, private or personal interest, when such employment or service conflicts with the proper discharge of his/her official or public duties or would tend to impair his/her independent judgment or action in the performance of such duties, unless otherwise permitted by law and unless disclosure is made as provided in this article. 
(b)  No member of city council, including the mayor, or any immediate family member of such official, shall be employed or hired by the city in any capacity during such official's term or within one year of expiration of such official's term of office. 
(c)  Any board of adjustments and appeals or planning commission member who applies for and obtains city employment shall resign from such board or commission no later than the member's effective date of employment, unless such requirement is waived by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-535), 3-24-2004; Ord. No. 3-2010,  1, 2-10-2010) 
Sec. 2-159. - Appearances. 
    No official shall, in a professional capacity, for example, as an attorney, architect, developer, consultant or engineer, represent any private person, business or entity other than himself/herself, his/her spouse or minor children, before city council, or any public body or municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-540), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-160. - Use of public property. 
    No official shall request or permit the unauthorized use of city-owned vehicles, equipment, materials or property for personal or private convenience or profit. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-545), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-161. - Equality of treatment. 
    No official shall grant any special consideration, treatment or advantage to any person other than that which is available to every other person. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-550), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-162. - Requests for opinion. 
    Upon full disclosure of facts to the city manager, an official may request an advisory opinion of the city manager, with the advice of the city attorney, regarding the application of this article to the official. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-555), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-163. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city council may appoint special counsel to investigate or initiate prosecution for any alleged violation of this article. 
(b)  Any city resident, property owner, tenant, or business owner who alleges that an official with the exception of the city manager has violated any provision of this section shall file a written notice of complaint with the city manager who may determine whether or not the allegation is frivolous or groundless, or the city manager may refer the matter to the city attorney for a determination of whether or not the allegation is frivolous or groundless. For the purposes of this section, the term "frivolous" shall mean that there is no legal or factual basis, which rationally supports the allegation. If it is determined that the allegation is not frivolous or groundless, the city manager (who may appoint an independent, outside party to fully investigate the matter) shall submit a written report of the investigation and take such action as necessary to ensure compliance with the requirement in this article. The city manager shall keep the city council informed as to the status of all allegations. 
(1)  If a member of the city council alleges that a violation of this article has occurred, the city manager (who may retain special counsel) shall investigate the allegation and provide a written report of the results of such investigation. The special counsel, upon council's approval, may also take such action under law to ensure compliance with this section. 
(2)  In the event the complaint is against or involves the city manager or the city attorney, the mayor with the approval of city council may retain special counsel, who shall receive the written complaint, investigate and make a determination as to whether a reasonable basis exists that a violation may have occurred. The results of this investigation shall be reported to the city council who shall take such action as permitted by law to ensure compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(c)  City officials shall not threaten or otherwise discriminate against any official, regarding terms, conditions, location or privileges of office on the basis of any report made against any other official suspected of violating this section, or for participating in any investigation, hearing or inquiry conducted pursuant to this article. This section, however, shall not apply to any official whom knowingly or with reckless indifference to the truth makes a false report or provides false information. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-560), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-164. - Violations; penalties. 
    It shall be unlawful to violate any requirement of this article. In addition to the penalties set forth in this Code, the city shall have the authority when a violation of this article has occurred, to bring civil action or proceeding at law or in equity for a judgment enjoining any violation of the provisions of this article or requiring the relinquishment of any prohibited interest or the voiding of any contract or transaction, considering, but not limited to, the interests of the city and any third persons who may be adversely affected or injured thereby. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-565), 3-24-2004) 
Sec. 2-165. - Distribution. 
    The city clerk shall cause a copy of this code of ethics to be distributed to every official of the city within seven days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article was derived. Every official shall be provided a copy before entering upon the duties of the office. 
(Ord. No. 4-2004,  1(2-570), 3-24-2004) 
Secs. 2-166-2-183. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CODE OF CONDUCT 

Sec. 2-184. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  All council members, which for the purposes of this article include the mayor and mayor pro tem should: 
(1)  Fully participate in city council meetings and other public forums while demonstrating respect, kindness, consideration, and courtesy to others; 
(2)  Prepare in advance of council meetings and be familiar with issues on the agenda; 
(3)  Represent the city at ceremonial functions; 
(4)  Be respectful of other people's time; 
(5)  Stay focused and act efficiently during public meetings; 
(6)  Serve as a model of leadership and civility to the community; 
(7)  Inspire public confidence in city government; 
(8)  Demonstrate honesty and integrity in every action and statement; 
(9)  Participate in scheduled activities to increase team effectiveness and review council procedures, such as this code of conduct; and 
(10)  Recommend committees, as appropriate, for council approval. 
(b)  All council members shall, if absent from a meeting, notify the city clerk or mayor as soon as possible prior to the meeting. 
(c)  All council members shall be on time for all meetings and promptly return from any recess or break. 
(d)  The mayor will chair meetings of council unless the mayor pro tem or another council member is designated as chair of a specific meeting. The chair shall be responsible for conducting the meeting in an orderly and democratic fashion; shall maintain order, decorum and the fair and equitable treatment of all speakers; shall keep discussions and questions focused on specific agenda items under discussion; shall decide all questions of order, subject to a council member's right to appeal to council as a whole and may call a recess at any time to determine a rule of order or at the request of a majority of council or for convenience of council members or staff. 
(e)  In the event any person interrupts the business of council or causes a disorder, the chair may require such person to cease such behavior and/or leave council chambers or the meeting room. Should such person fail to comply, the chair may request a police officer to be summoned to have such person removed. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(300), 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-185. - Policies and protocol. 
(a)  Ceremonial events. Requests for a city representative at ceremonial events should be directed to the city manager who will inform council of the request. The mayor shall serve as the designated city representative. If the mayor is unavailable, then the mayor pro tem may attend. If neither the mayor nor the mayor pro tem is available the mayor, mayor pro tem or council shall determine who will represent the city. 
(b)  Correspondence. Unless council specifically directs otherwise, it need not acknowledge the receipt of correspondence or other documents addressed to it at a council meeting. The city manager shall, at the direction of council, prepare official letters in response to public inquiries and concerns. These letters will be signed by the mayor unless the mayor requests that they be signed by council or a specific council member or the city manager. If correspondence or documents are addressed only to an individual council member, such council member shall consult with the city manager regarding a response. 
(c)  City supplies. Council members shall use city letterhead or other city supplies only in the performance of their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(305), 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-186. - Council meeting rules of speaking and decorum. 
(a)  Recognition. No council member shall speak until such member has been addressed and/or recognized by the chair. When a council member is speaking, no other council member shall interrupt or conduct a private conversation, and council members shall refer to one another formally by title followed by the member's last name. 
(b)  Decorum. 
(1)  No council member shall leave the chambers while the chair is putting a question or other form of business before council. 
(2)  No council member shall engage in conversation or commit any other act tending to distract the attention of the council from the business before it. 
(3)  When speaking or debating, members shall confine their remarks to the question under discussion or debate and shall not engage in discussion directed to personal matters or issues. Council members shall respect the divergent opinions and comments of others and shall not engage in personal, verbal attacks or comments or behavior disrespectful of each other or other persons. 
(4)  If a council member is personally offended by the remarks of another council member, the offended council member should make notes of the comments and may request that the chair provide the council member an opportunity to respond and request that the other council member justify or apologize for the comments. The chair shall maintain control of such interaction. 
(c)  Protest. Any council member has the right to protest any action of council, stating the reasons therefore and have same entered on the record, provided such reasons do not impugn the motives or personal character of any council member. 
(d)  Limitation of debate. When a matter is before council for action, no council member shall speak more than twice before all council members who wish to speak have spoken at least once. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(310), 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-187. - Council conduct with public. 
    Council members should not display signs of partiality, prejudice or disrespect toward members of the public participating in any public meeting and council members should make every effort to be fair and impartial in listening to public testimony. More specifically, council members should be welcoming to all speakers and treat each with respect; actively and attentively listen to all speakers; if clarification is needed or a response requested to a comment from the public, ask the chair for permission to respond; avoid personal attacks and disrespectful comments concerning members of the public; and avoid making promises on behalf of the entire council, except where specifically authorized. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(315), 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-188. - Council conduct with staff. 
(a)  Council members shall have the authority to direct the city manager with respect to the manager's duties and may discuss all matters of city operations with staff. However, council members are prohibited from giving any direct orders specifically to any city employee, or soliciting political support from any employee for a council member's campaign for any elected or appointed office. 
(b)  In interacting with staff, council members should treat all staff as professionals, not disrupt staff in the performance of their duties, not publicly criticize individual staff members, direct all questions of staff through the city manager or applicable department head and not attend staff functions unless invited by the city manager or department head. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(320), 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-189. - Council conduct with public entities. 
    Council members appearing on behalf of the city before any other governmental entity shall support and advocate the city's stated position. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(325), 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-190. - Council conduct with boards and commissions. 
    Council members shall not contact any board or commission member to lobby on behalf of any person or public or private corporate entity or organization involved in any matter before the board or commission. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(330), 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-191. - Council conduct with media. 
(a)  The mayor is the designated spokesperson of council. 
(b)  Council members contacted individually by the media should inform the media that any response they provide is their individual opinion and that the mayor is the designated spokesperson of council. In dealing with the media, council members are advised to never go "off the record" and to choose their words cautiously and avoid sarcastic, disparaging or sardonic comments. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(335), 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-192. - Council development and education. 
(a)  Council members may, with permission of council, attend conferences, workshops or seminars designed to further a council member's knowledge and skills of city related matters. 
(b)  If approved by council, expenses for such activities may be authorized for transportation, mileage, parking, food, lodging and participant fees. 
(c)  Receipts are required for all reimbursement and council members shall not submit any unauthorized, altered or fraudulent receipts. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(340), 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-193. - Discipline. 
    Council members who violate the requirements of this Code, the code of ethics or are convicted or plead guilty or no contest to a felony offense may, if voluntary compliance and/or sanctions cannot be agreed upon, be brought before council upon the written complaint of any council member, employee or registered elector of the city. Upon receipt of a complaint, council may appoint a special prosecutor to determine if probable cause exists. If either council or a special prosecutor determines that probable cause exists, council may, in addition to any prosecution in the municipal court brought by a special prosecutor, set the matter for a hearing before council. Such hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the basic principles of due process and include by example, written notice of charges and the opportunity to both present and cross examine witnesses and documents. If, upon conclusion of the hearing, a majority of council finds that by a preponderance of the evidence a violation or conviction has occurred, it may impose sanctions that include public reprimand, censure, loss of committee assignments or other council duties and expulsion. Expulsion from council shall only be imposed where council finds that the nature of the violation(s) is so egregious that the integrity of the council member is undermined to the extent that the council member could not adequately perform as a representative of the city. 
(Ord. No. 19-2004,  1(345), 11-23-2004) 
Chapter 6 - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to adopt police ordinances, C.R.S.  31-15-401; municipal authority to license, regulate and tax businesses, C.R.S.  31-15-501. Colorado Constitution, art. XX,  6. 

Sec. 6-1. - Intent. 
    The intent of this chapter is to promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare by regulating adult entertainment establishments through the enactment of reasonable regulations that limit the adverse secondary effects of adult entertainment establishments. This chapter is not intended to suppress any speech or expressive activities protected by the First Amendment of the United States Constitution or Article II,  10 of the Colorado Constitution. This chapter is not, however, intended to condone or legitimize the distribution of obscene material. 
(Code 1986,  3-1) 
Sec. 6-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult arcade means any commercial establishment in which the public is permitted or invited where, for any form of consideration, one or more motion picture projectors, slide projectors, image or virtual reality producing machines or similar machines, for viewing by five or fewer persons per machine at any one time, are used regularly to show films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides, digital images, electronic reproductions or photographs describing, simulating or depicting specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult cabaret means a nightclub, bar, restaurant or similar commercial establishment, which, for any form of consideration, features live performances which are characterized by the exposure of specified anatomical areas or by the exhibition of specified sexual activities. 
    Adult entertainment establishment means an adult arcade, adult store, adult cabaret, adult motion picture theater, adult sexual encounter establishment, or adult theater, except an establishment where a medical practitioner, psychologist, psychiatrist or similar professional licensed by the state engages in approved and recognized sexual therapy. 
    Adult motion picture theater means a commercial establishment which is characterized by the showing, for any form of consideration, of films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, digital images or other visual representations that have an emphasis on depicting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult sexual encounter establishment means a business or commercial establishment other than an adult cabaret which, as one if its primary business purposes, offers, for any form of consideration, a place where two or more persons may congregate, associate or consort for the purpose of specified sexual activities or the exposure of specified anatomical areas, when one or more of the persons exposes any specified anatomical area. 
    Adult store means any commercial establishment which, as one of its principal business purposes, offers for sale or rent for any form of consideration one or more of the following: 
(1)  Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, compact discs, digital images or other visual representations which are characterized by their emphasis on the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
(2)  Instruments, devices or paraphernalia designed for use in connection with specified sexual activities. 
    Adult theater means a theater, auditorium or similar commercial establishment, which, for any form of consideration, regularly features live performances, which are characterized by an emphasis on exposure of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities. 
    Convicted means having been found guilty by a judge or a jury or entering a guilty plea or a plea of nolo contendere, and includes deferred judgments, deferred sentences, deferred adjudications and plea bargains, whether or not an appeal of such conviction is pending; excluding any conviction overturned or vacated by appeal or other force of law. 
    Employee means a person who works or performs work or service in or for a sexually oriented business on a full-time, part-time or contract basis, with or without compensation, regardless of whether such person is designated as an employee, independent contractor, agent, volunteer or other status; excluding any person on the premises for repair or maintenance of the premises or for delivering or removing tangible personal property to or from the premises. 
    Licensed premises means the building or structure in which a licensed adult entertainment establishment is operating. 
    Manager means any employee other than a licensee who is employed by an adult entertainment establishment to act as manager or supervisor of the employees, finances, patrons of the business or is otherwise responsible for operation of the business. 
    Specified anatomical areas means any of the following: 
(1)  Human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus or female breasts below a point immediately above the top of the areola, which are not completely and opaquely covered. 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
    Specified crime means and includes the following crimes committed under the penal or criminal code of any municipality, county, state or country: sex crimes against children; sexual abuse; sexual assault; possession or distribution of child pornography; distribution, sale or use of a controlled substance as defined by law; or prostitution, promotion of prostitution or pandering. 
    Specified sexual activity means any of the following: 
(1)  Fondling or other intentional touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus or female breasts. 
(2)  Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation and sodomy. 
(3)  Masturbation, actual or simulated. 
(4)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal. 
(5)  Human excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in subsections (1) through (4) hereof. 
(Code 1986,  3-2) 
Sec. 6-3. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an adult entertainment establishment in the city without having first obtained a license therefor from the city as set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1986,  3-3) 
Sec. 6-4. - License application. 
(a)  Applicants for an adult entertainment establishment license shall submit a written application to the city clerk, which includes the following: 
(1)  The name, address, telephone number and current photograph of passport size and quality and date of birth of the applicant and, each of the proposed licensees, officers, partners, directors and registered agents. 
(2)  The trade name of the applicant and copies of all documents recording the trade name, including the trade name affidavit. 
(3)  The name of any other adult entertainment establishments in which any officer, director or partner has a financial interest. 
(4)  The address of the premises to be licensed. 
(5)  If the applicant is a corporation, copies of the articles of incorporation, bylaws and last annual report. 
(6)  Copies of documents demonstrating that the applicant has a legal right to possession of the premises to be licensed. 
(7)  A sketch, drawing or diagram drawn to scale and showing the configuration of the premises, including total floor area to be occupied by the adult entertainment establishments. 
(8)  The type or types of adult entertainment establishments proposed, such as an adult store, adult cabaret, adult theater and/or adult motion picture theater. 
(9)  Whether the applicant, any partner, officer, or director has within five years from the date of the application, had any adult entertainment establishment license requested or issued from any other governmental entity denied, suspended, revoked or not renewed and if so, the name and address of such business and dates and reasons for such denial, suspension, revocation or nonrenewal. 
(10)  If the applicant, any partner, officer, or director has, within five years from the date of application, ever been convicted of any specified crime as defined and, if so, a complete description of any such offense; including date of violation, date of conviction, jurisdiction and any disposition, including any fine or sentence imposed and whether the terms of any sentence have been fully completed. 
(b)  Each application shall be verified and acknowledged to be true by the applicant or the managing partner, president or other officer having the authority to sign for the applicant. 
(c)  Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in an amount to be set by resolution of the city council, which application fee shall be in addition to any other applicable license fees imposed by this chapter. 
(Code 1986,  3-4) 
Sec. 6-5. - Background investigations. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a completed application, the city clerk shall cause to be performed, a background investigation of the applicant and its officers, directors and partners, and the information contained in the application. 
(b)  The city clerk is authorized to cause to be investigated any fact related to any of the criterion set forth in this chapter that may be relevant to determine the eligibility of the applicant for an adult entertainment establishment license. 
(c)  The city clerk may seek and obtain the assistance of law enforcement agencies and building officials in conducting the background investigation. 
(d)  The background investigation shall be completed within 30 days of receipt of the completed application. 
(Code 1986,  3-5) 
Sec. 6-6. - Issuance or denial. 
    Within seven days of the completion of the background investigation, the city clerk shall either issue the adult entertainment establishment license or issue a written statement of denial. The license and/or statement of denial shall be sent via United States mail, postage prepaid, to the applicant at the address provided on the application. The city clerk shall issue the license unless one or more of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  The applicant is overdue in payment to the city of taxes, fees, fines or penalties related to the operation of an adult entertainment establishment. 
(2)  The applicant or any of its officers, directors or partners is under 18 years of age. 
(3)  The applicant is not legally authorized to conduct business under applicable state or federal law, municipal ordinance or judicial order; 
(4)  The applicant has knowingly provided false information to the city on an application for an adult entertainment establishment license; 
(5)  The location of the proposed adult entertainment establishment does not comply with the location and distance requirements set forth in the city's zoning ordinance; 
(6)  The premises in which the adult entertainment establishment is proposed to be located is in violation of the city's building codes and regulations including the fire code. 
(7)  The applicant or any of its directors, officers or partners has been convicted of a specified crime, or had a sexually oriented business license denied, suspended, revoked or not renewed, in the five years preceding the date of the application. 
(8)  To appeal the city clerk's denial the applicant must, within ten days of the date of the denials issuance, submit a written notice of appeal to the city clerk requesting a hearing before city council. The hearing shall be held at the next regularly scheduled council meeting, but no later than ten days after receipt of the written request. 
a.  At the hearing, the applicant, who may be represented by legal counsel, may cross examine any findings of the city clerk and present additional evidence, either documentary or through witness testimony, which is relevant to the applicant's eligibility for an adult entertainment establishment license. 
b.  At the conclusion of the hearing or within ten days thereafter, the city council shall either determine, by a preponderance of the evidence, that a specified ground for denial has not been sustained and order that the city clerk issue the adult entertainment establishment license, or issue a written order denying the application for the sexually oriented business license on the basis that the city clerk's grounds for denial have been sustained. 
c.  To appeal city council's denial, the applicant must, within ten days of the date of issuance of city council's order sustaining the city clerk's denial, submit a written notice of appeal to the presiding judge of the city's municipal court. 
d.  The municipal court judge shall hold a hearing within ten days of receipt of a notice of appeal and issue a decision within the time lines, procedure and standard of proof set forth in subsections (8)a and b of this section. 
e.  Any appeal of the municipal judge's decision shall be in accordance with the applicable state or federal law. 
(Code 1986,  3-6) 
Sec. 6-7. - Annual license fee. 
    Approved applications shall be subject to an annual license fee as set forth by resolution of city council. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to pay in full the annual license fee. 
(Code 1986,  3-7) 
Sec. 6-8. - Term of license; renewal. 
(a)  All adult entertainment establishment licenses issued under this chapter shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance, unless revoked or suspended as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Written application for renewal of an adult entertainment establishment license shall be filed with the city clerk, on forms provided by the city clerk, at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the current license, together with the applicable nonrefundable license renewal and annual license fee. If an application for renewal is not timely filed, the licensee must re-apply for a new license. 
(c)  Applications for license renewals shall be subject to the same procedures as for new license applications. 
(d)  Each application for a renewal license shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable renewal application fee in an amount set by resolution of the city council, which fee shall be in addition to any other applicable license fees imposed by this chapter. 
(Code 1986,  3-8) 
Sec. 6-9. - License nontransferable. 
    An adult entertainment establishment license issued under this chapter is nontransferable. 
(Code 1986,  3-9) 
Sec. 6-10. - Posting of license.
