Chapter 22 - BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General authority to license, tax and regulate businesses, C.R.S.  31-15-501(c). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS AND OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means all trades, vocations, occupations, professions, enterprises and establishments and all other kinds of activities and matters, together with all devices, machines, vehicles and appurtenances used therein, any of which are conducted for gain, financial profit, advantage or benefit either directly or indirectly, on any premises in this city or anywhere else within its jurisdiction. This includes, but is not limited to, all retail sales, wholesale sales, services, home-based business sales or services and the rental of any real estate, residence, structure, units or parcels of ground. 
    Licensee means any person to whom a business license is issued. 
    Specialty license means any license required by this chapter or by other applicable law, other than a general business license, for the operation of a specific type of business. 
(Ord. No. 5-2005,  2(12-16), 5-11-2005; Ord. No. 6-2014,  2, 4-28-2014 ; Ord. No. 1-2015,  1, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-32. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate and maintain a business in the city without first obtaining a general business license to conduct such business as required by this article. Adult entertainment establishments as defined in article XXVII of chapter 56 of the Code, shall be required to obtain a general business license. 
(b)  A separate business license shall be required for each location of a business operating within the city. For the purposes of this subsection, the term "location" shall mean the property upon which the business is situated and any adjacent property under the ownership or control of the licensee. 
(c)  A copy of every license granted under the provisions of this article shall be posted in a conspicuous location at the place of business for the full term of the license. If a person operates and maintains a business within the city but no physical place of business exists within the city, as in the case of a contractor, peddler, solicitor, canvasser, transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor, the license shall be carried on the person engaging in the business activity. It shall be the duty of each licensee to exhibit the license upon the request of any law enforcement officer, inspector, or other officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 5-2005,  2(12-17), 5-11-2005; Ord. No. 1-2015,  2, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-33. - License application. 
(a)  Submission and review; inspection for compliance of proposed business. Applicants for a general business license shall submit an application to the city clerk on forms provided by the city clerk. The city clerk shall forward the application to all applicable departments of general government which shall review the application and/or lawfully inspect the premises to determine whether the proposed business is in compliance with all applicable ordinances, laws, codes, rules and regulations enforced by the department. 
(b)  Contents of application. All applications shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name of the applicant and name and address of the business; 
(2)  Names, addresses and phone numbers of all owners or, in the case of corporations, all corporate officers and directors; 
(3)  A detailed statement of the kind or nature of the business or service and the number of employees; 
(4)  Evidence that the applicant has obtained all required sales and use tax licenses from the city; and 
(5)  Detailed emergency contact information, including, but not limited to, the name, address and telephone number of a local manager or agent, alarm system monitoring service provider and type of alarm, burglar, fire, holdup or panic, maintained on the premises. 
(c)  License renewal. An application for renewal of a business license shall be filed annually with the city clerk, on forms provided by the city clerk. Licensees who fail to renew a license prior to its expiration shall be assessed a delinquent renewal fee plus a penalty of 20 percent of the delinquency fee for each month or portion thereof for which the renewal is delinquent. In the event a suspension or revocation proceeding is pending when a license renewal is filed, the applicant shall be issued a provisional license by the city clerk and the application for renewal shall not be acted upon until the suspension or revocation proceeding has been completed. Any changes to the information provided by the applicant on the initial application pursuant to subsection (b) above shall be updated on the renewal application. 
(d)  Application fee. All applications shall be accompanied by the full amount of the fee charged for such license. Such fee is nonrefundable. 
(Ord. No. 5-2005,  2(12-18), 5-11-2005) 
Sec. 22-34. - License fees. 
(a)  The annual license and delinquent renewal fees shall be set by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  The annual license required by this article is for the privilege of pursuing the designated business, profession, vocation, or occupation for one year from the date of issuance of the license. 
(c)  Nonprofit organizations with 501(c)(3) status in accordance with 26 U.S.C.  501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code are exempt from the annual license fee. 
(Ord. No. 5-2005,  2(12-19), 5-11-2005; Ord. No. 1-2015,  3, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-35. - License nontransferable. 
    No license issued in accordance with this article may be transferred or assigned. 
(Ord. No. 5-2005,  2(12-20), 5-11-2005) 
Sec. 22-36. - Address posting requirements. 
    Each licensee shall post on the licensed premises or structure the numeric address, and if applicable the unit number, in a conspicuous place visible from any roadway access or public access area. Unit numbers shall be posted on each unit. Posting shall be in letters/numbers not less than four inches in height and visible for a minimum of 100 feet. 
(Ord. No. 5-2005,  2(12-21), 5-11-2005) 
Sec. 22-37. - License denial. 
(a)  An application shall be denied by the city clerk based on any of the following grounds: 
(1)  All applicable provisions of this article and state law have not been met; 
(2)  The required fee has not been paid in full; 
(3)  The application is incomplete or contains false, misleading or fraudulent statements; 
(4)  Nonconformance of the business, premises, building or land use with the Code; 
(5)  Prior or ongoing violations of law in connection with, on or about the premises of the business; or 
(6)  Any reason that would in accordance with this article justify suspension or revocation of a license. 
(b)  No license shall be effective until the applicant has lawful possession of the proposed business premises, a city sales and use tax license, and any other licenses required by applicable law. 
(c)  The city clerk shall within five days of the decision to deny a license send written notice to the applicant. The notice shall inform the applicant of the reason for denial and that the decision may be appealed to the city manager as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 5-2005,  2(12-22), 5-11-2005; Ord. No. 1-2015,  4, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-38. - License suspension, revocation or non-renewal. 
(a)  The city manager may suspend, revoke or not renew a license if, after notice and hearing, the city manager finds that: 
(1)  The licensee has failed to pay all required fees; 
(2)  The licensee is overdue upon payment to the city of taxes, fines, fees, or penalties assessed against or imposed upon the licensee; 
(3)  The licensee has made any false statement in the license or renewal application as to any of the facts required to be stated in such application; 
(4)  The licensee has failed to file such reports or furnish such information as required by the provisions of this Code relating to such license; 
(5)  The licensee has refused to allow any inspection of the licensed premises authorized by the Code; 
(6)  The licensee, or any officer, agent, or employee thereof, either knowingly or without the exercise of due care to prevent the same, has violated any of the provisions of this article relating to such license, or any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant thereto; 
(7)  Any fact or condition exists, which, if it had existed or had been known to exist at the time of the license or renewal application, would have warranted the city clerk to refuse to issue or renew such license; 
(8)  The licensee has failed to operate the licensed premises in accordance with any building, fire, health or zoning statute, code, ordinance, or regulation, whether federal, state, or local; 
(9)  The licensee has knowingly permitted or encouraged, or has knowingly and unreasonably failed to prevent a nuisance within the meaning of this Code from occurring in or about the licensed premises; 
(10)  The licensee, or any officer, agent, or employee thereof, has committed a criminal offense under federal, state, or local law in or about the licensed premises or in association with the operation of the licensed business for which a conviction has been obtained, or has knowingly permitted the same to be committed on such premises by any other person. 
(b)  If the city manager finds that the license should be suspended or revoked, the licensee shall be provided written notice of such suspension or revocation and the reasons therefor within 20 days following the date of the hearing or such other time as is specified by the provisions of this article relating to such license. 
(c)  No suspension under this section shall be for a period of time longer than 180 days. 
(Ord. No. 5-2005,  2(12-23), 5-11-2005; Ord. No. 1-2015,  5, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-38.5. - Emergency suspension. 
    If the city manager finds that probable cause exists for the suspension or revocation of any license as the result of conduct which constitutes a deliberate and willful violation of any applicable law, rule, or regulation, or which imposes an undue risk to the public health, safety, or welfare, the city manager may enter an order for the immediate suspension of such license, pending further investigation and hearing, for a period not exceeding 30 days. Such order shall be in writing, citing the reasons for such suspension, and shall be served upon the licensee or the licensee's agent forthwith upon its execution, together with a notice to appear before the city manager for a hearing to show cause why the license should not be suspended or revoked. Such hearing shall take place no later than 30 days following the date upon which such order is issued. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  6, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-39. - Hearing. 
(a)  Application denial. Any applicant who has been denied a license by the city clerk may appeal the decision to the city manager by submitting an appeal request in writing to the city manager within 20 days following the date of such decision. Such request shall set forth the reasons for the appeal. Only those matters specifically addressed in such request shall be considered by the city manager. The city manager shall conduct an appeal hearing no later than 20 days following the receipt of such request. 
(b)  Suspension, revocation or non-renewal. Where there is probable cause to believe that grounds for suspension, revocation, or denial of renewal exists, the city manager shall notify the licensee in writing of the contemplated action and, in general, the grounds therefor. The city manager shall further order the licensee to appear before the city manager for the purpose of a hearing on a specified date to show cause why such suspension, revocation, or denial of renewal should not occur. The hearing shall take place no later than 20 days following the issuance of such order. 
(c)  Hearing procedures. 
(1)  At any hearing, the city manager shall hear such statements and consider such evidence as the city staff and the applicant or licensee shall offer which is relevant to the grounds alleged in the notice. The city manager shall make findings of fact from the statements and evidence offered as to whether based upon a preponderance of the evidence there exists grounds to support denial, suspension, revocation or non-renewal of the license. If such evidence exists, the city manager shall issue an order for such denial, suspension, revocation or non-renewal. 
(2)  The order of the city manager made pursuant to this subsection shall be a final administrative decision subject to judicial review in the district court pursuant to Rule 106(a)(4) of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure. The failure of an applicant or licensee to seek review of such order within 30 days of the city manager's final administrative decision shall constitute a waiver of any right to contest the denial, suspension, revocation or non-renewal of the license. 
(3)  The city manager shall have the power to administer oaths, issue subpoenas, and, when necessary, grant continuances. Subpoenas may be issued to require the presence of persons and the production of papers, books, and records necessary to the city manager's determination. It is unlawful for any person to fail to comply with any subpoena issued by the city manager. A subpoena shall be served in the same manner as a subpoena issued by the municipal court. 
(4)  All hearings held before the city manager regarding denial, suspension, revocation or non-renewal of a license shall be recorded by an electronic recording device. Any person requesting a transcript of such record shall post a deposit in the amount required by the city manager, and shall pay all costs of preparing such record. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  7, 6-8-2015 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1-2015 ,  7, adopted June 8, 2015, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 22-40. - Right of entry to licensed premises. 
(a)  Any city employee or authorized agent thereof shall be permitted access to any licensed premises at all times such premises is occupied or open for business, in the course of their duties to conduct inspections for the purpose of enforcing the charter and ordinances of the city, and any rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to whom a license has been issued, or any officer, agent or employee thereof, to refuse to submit to or permit such inspection or for any such person to interfere with such inspection. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  8, 6-8-2015 ) 
Secs. 22-41-22-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PAWNBROKERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, adopted June 8, 2015, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III,  22-76-22-95, pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, C.R.S.  12-56-101 et seq.; local licensing and regulation of pawnbrokers, C.R.S.  12-56-102. 

Sec. 22-76. - Definitions. 
    The following terms as used in this article shall have the following meanings unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Contract for purchase means a contract entered into between a pawnbroker and a customer pursuant to which money is advanced to a customer by the pawnbroker on the delivery of tangible personal property by the customer on the condition that the customer, for a fixed price and within a fixed period of time to be no less than 30 days, has the option to cancel said contract. 
    Finance director means the city's finance director or the director's authorized designee. 
    Fixed price means that amount agreed upon to cancel a contract for purchase during the option period. Said fixed price shall not exceed one-fifth of the original purchase price for each month, plus the original purchase price. 
    Fixed time means that period of time, to be no less than 30 days, as set forth in a contract for purchase, for an option to cancel said contract. 
    Manager means an employee of a pawnbroker who directs, manages and supervises the business of the pawnbroker. 
    Option means the fixed time and the fixed price agreed upon by the customer and the pawnbroker in which a contract for purchase may be, but does not have to be, rescinded by the customer. 
    Pawnbroker means a person regularly engaged in the business of making contracts for purchase or purchase transactions in the course of such person's business. 
    Pledge or pledged property means any tangible personal property deposited with a pawnbroker pursuant to a contract for purchase in the course of his/her business as defined in this section. 
    Pledgor means a customer who delivers a pledge into the possession of a pawnbroker. 
    Purchase transaction means the purchase by a pawnbroker of tangible personal property for resale, other than newly manufactured tangible personal property, which has not previously been sold at retail, when such purchase does not constitute a contract for purchase. 
    Tangible personal property means all personal property other than choses in action, securities, or printed evidences of indebtedness, which property is deposited with or otherwise actually delivered into the possession of a pawnbroker in the course of the pawnbroker's business in connection with a contract for purchase or a purchase transaction. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-77. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a pawnbroker without first obtaining a license to operate such business in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-78. - Licensing application; fee. 
    All applicants for a pawnbroker license shall file an application for such license with the city clerk on forms to be provided by the city. The application for a license under this article shall contain the information required by this article and any other pertinent information required by the police department. Each individual applicant, partner of a partnership, officer, director, and holder of ten percent or more of the corporate stock of a corporate applicant, and all managers shall be named in each application, and each of them shall be photographed and fingerprinted by the police department. Each individual applicant, partnership, or corporate applicant shall, in addition, furnish as an attachment to and part of such application evidence that the proposed establishment meets the requirements of the city's zoning code, proof of the applicant's right to possession of premises wherein the pawnbroker business will be conducted, a financial questionnaire, consent to release of financial information, and a current personal financial statement or balance sheet and income account statement for the preceding 12-month period prior to the date of the application. Each corporate applicant shall furnish evidence that it is in good standing under the statutes of the state, or, in the case of a foreign corporation, evidence that it is currently authorized to do business in the state. The license issued under this article shall be applicable only for the location identified in the license application, and only for the applicant making the license application. Each applicant shall pay a nonrefundable application fee at the time of filing an application in an amount as established by a resolution of city council. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-79. - License fee. 
    The city finds, determines and declares that considering the nature of the pawnbroker business and the relationship of such business to the municipal welfare, as well as the relationship thereto to the expenditures required of the city and all other matters properly to be considered in relation thereto, the classification of such business as a separate type of business or occupation requiring a separate license fee is reasonable, proper, uniform, nondiscriminatory, and necessary for a just and proper distribution of costs for city services. Accordingly, the city hereby requires that each pawnbroker pay an annual license fee in an amount established by a resolution of city council. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-80. - Nontransferability of license. 
    Absent the prior written approval of the city, licenses issued pursuant to this article are not transferable. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-81. - License renewal. 
    Annual renewal requests must be filed with the city clerk no later than the first day of December of each calendar year and shall be made under oath. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-82. - Bond required. 
    As a requirement of the licensing process, the applicant shall furnish a good and sufficient bond with a surety to be approved by the city clerk in the sum of $5,000.00. Such bond shall be conditioned upon the licensee's faithful observance of the requirements of this article and conditioned upon the safekeeping of return of all articles in pledge by such pawnbroker. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-83. - Insurance required. 
    As a requirement of the licensing process, the applicant shall provide fire and property damage insurance for all property the pawnbroker holds by contract, in the minimum amount of one-half of such property's contracted value in case of damage or destruction. The applicant must provide the city clerk proof of such insurance coverage before a pawnbroker license is issued. Proof of this insurance coverage must be provided each time a request for renewal is filed with the city clerk. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-84. - City planner and code official approval. 
    As part of the licensing process and prior to the issuance of any pawnbroker license, the applicant shall obtain and submit to the city clerk a letter, from the city planner and building and fire code officials, or his/her designee, stating that the proposed business is in compliance with all of the city's zoning, building and fire code rules and regulations. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-85. - Investigation and approval of applicants. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a properly completed application, as determined by the city clerk, together with all information required in connection therewith, fingerprints and photographs, and payment of the application fee, the police department shall conduct an investigation of the background, experience, character and financial responsibility of each individual applicant, the partners of a partnership, officers, directors, and holders of ten percent or more of the corporate stock of a corporate applicant, and a proposed pawnbroker establishment. 
(b)  Once the city clerk receives verification that the applicant has met the bond and insurance requirements, and is in compliance with all applicable city zoning regulations and the city's, building and fire codes and has received the investigative report from the police department, the city clerk shall issue the applicant a pawnbroker license unless the city clerk determines that grounds for denial of the license exist as set forth in section 22-86. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-86. - Denial of license. 
(a)  The application for, or renewal of, a pawnbroker license may be denied by the city clerk on grounds including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  A finding that an individual applicant, partner, officer or director of a corporation, and/or holder of ten percent or more of the stock of a corporate applicant or manager of a pawnbroker establishment: 
a.  Fails at any time, to meet the qualifications required of an applicant by this article; 
b.  Violates any provision of this article or other ordinance of the city governing the activities permitted by the licensee; 
c.  Obtained the license by fraud or misrepresentation; or 
d.  Has been convicted of a felony or any offense involving moral turpitude including, but not limited to, theft, fraud, robbery, burglary, larceny, or deceit; and such conviction, as determined by the police department, would create a danger to the public health, safety, or welfare if the licensee were to continue to engage in such conduct. 
(2)  A finding that an applicant is not financially responsible, is not in good standing, or is not authorized to do business in Colorado. As used herein, the term "financially responsible" means having sufficient income and assets to defray expenses and provide for liabilities of the business as they become due. 
(3)  A finding that the applicant is not in compliance with all applicable city tax, zoning, building and fire code regulations and requirements. 
(4)  The city clerk shall make a decision to accept or deny the applicant's license or renewal thereof no later than 30 days after the city clerk has received all forms, documents and items required of the applicant by this section and the results of the police department's investigation required by section 22-85. 
(b)  The city clerk shall not deny an applicant's request for a license without notice to the applicant of the reasons for such denial, and without the applicant being given an opportunity for an appeal of the city clerk's decision as set forth in section 22-87. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-87. - Revocation or suspension of license. 
(a)  A pawnbroker license may be suspended or revoked under this article if: 
(1)  The licensee fails at any time to meet the qualifications required of an applicant by this article; 
(2)  The licensee violates any provision of this article or other ordinance of the city governing the activities permitted by the licensee; 
(3)  The licensee obtained the license by fraud or misrepresentation; or 
(4)  The licensee has been convicted of a felony or any offense involving moral turpitude including, but not limited to, theft, fraud, robbery, burglary, larceny or deceit; and such conviction, as determined by the police department, would create a danger to the public health, safety, or welfare if the licensee were to continue to engage in such conduct. 
(b)  If the city clerk is made aware of the grounds in subsection (a), the city clerk shall have the authority to suspend or revoke the license. 
(c)  No suspension or revocation is final until the licensee has been given the opportunity for a hearing to address the suspension or revocation. Such hearing shall be held within 20 days of a written request for the hearing filed with the city clerk by the licensee affected. Such request must be submitted in writing to the city clerk no later than 14 calendar days of the date of the city clerk's order of denial, suspension or revocation. Appeal of a denial of a request for issuance of a pawnbroker's license, or renewal thereof, shall be conducted according to this subsection. The hearing shall be conducted as follows: 
(1)  Upon receipt of a request for a hearing, the city clerk shall set the matter for a hearing before the city manager who shall decide the matter. The city clerk shall, notify the applicant or licensee of the hearing date by mail. 
(2)  The city manager is granted the authority to sustain, reverse, or modify the city clerk's decision, and/or upon a showing by the applicant or licensee of mitigating factors, may suspend the license for a period of time and/or impose on the applicant or licensee reasonable conditions on the license or any renewal thereof to secure compliance with this article. 
(3)  Any hearing presented pursuant to this section shall be conducted in compliance with standards of procedural due process applicable to administrative hearings, including the right to present testimony and to confront witnesses. 
(4)  The city manager shall apply the following standards for review: 
a.  Whether the city clerk, through the order of revocation, suspension, or denial, abused its discretion; 
b.  Acted arbitrarily; or 
c.  Acted in excess of the city clerk's authority hereunder. 
(5)  Additionally, the licensee or applicant shall have the burden to show by a preponderance of the evidence why the revocation, suspension, or denial of a license, or renewal thereof, was improper under the above standards. It shall also be the burden of the licensee to establish the mitigation in contesting any order of revocation or suspension. 
(6)  The city manager shall conduct the hearing within 20 business days of filing the request for hearing and shall enter written findings of fact and conclusions of law, which shall be mailed to the licensee or applicant at the address shown on the license application. The hearing officer's decision shall be effective within three business days of the date of the written finding requirement by this subsection. 
(d)  If after a hearing, the suspension or revocation is upheld, the city clerk may include reasonable orders or conditions with which the person, whose license has been suspended or revoked, shall comply to protect any work in progress and the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(e)  No person whose license is revoked under this section is entitled to receive a refund of any part of the license fee paid for the license. 
(f)  No person who has had a license suspended or revoked under this section is entitled to obtain the same or any similar license under this section during the period of suspension or revocation, either in the person's own name or as a principal in another business that applies for a license. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-88. - Managers; change of owner, shareholder, partner, officer, director or manager. 
(a)  In the event of a change of owner, officer, director, or holder of more than ten percent of the shares of stock of a corporate license holder, partner of a partnership, or manager, disclosure in writing by amendment of the original application for the issuance of a pawnbroker's license thereof shall be made to the city clerk. 
(b)  Any new manager shall be photographed, fingerprinted and investigated as required in section 22-85. Failure of the applicant to request an amendment of the application, or failure to meet the prescribed standards and qualifications of section 22-86, shall constitute grounds for revocation, suspension, or nonrenewal of the license. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-89. - Required acts of pawnbrokers. 
(a)  A pawnbroker shall keep a numerical register in which shall be recorded the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, phone number(s), date of birth and social security number of the customer; 
(2)  The number of the customer's valid Colorado driver's license, or one of the following alternative forms of identification: 
a.  Valid Colorado identification card; 
b.  A valid driver's license, with photograph, issued by another state; 
c.  Military identification card; 
d.  Valid passport; 
e.  Alien registration card; 
f.  An identification document, with no photograph, issued by a state or the federal government. 
(3)  The date, time and place of the contract for purchase or purchase transaction; 
(4)  An accurate and detailed account and description of each item of tangible personal property, including, but not limited to, any trademark, identification number, serial number, model number, brand name, or other identifying marks on such property; 
(5)  The pawnbroker shall also obtain a written declaration of the customer's ownership which shall state that each piece of tangible personal property is solely owned by the customer, or shall have attached to such declaration a power of sale from any partial owner to the customer, how long the customer has owned each piece of property, whether the customer or someone else found the property, and, if the property was found, the details of the finding. 
(b)  If the contract for purchase or other purchase transaction involves more than one item, each item shall be recorded on the pawnbroker's register and on the customer's declaration of ownership. 
(c)  The customer shall sign his or her name in such register and provide a clear and identifiable imprint of the customer's right index finger in such register and on the declaration of ownership, and shall receive a copy of the contract of purchase or a receipt for the purchase transaction from the pawnbroker. 
(d)  Such register shall be made available to any local law enforcement agency for inspection at any reasonable time. 
(e)  The pawnbroker shall keep each register for at least three years after the date of the last transaction entered in the register. 
(f)  A pawnbroker shall hold all contracted goods for a period of ten days following the maturity date of the contract for purchase, during which time such goods shall be held separate and apart from any other tangible personal property, and shall not be changed in form or altered in any way. 
(g)  A pawnbroker shall hold all property purchased by him or her through a purchase transaction for 30 days following the date of purchase, during which time such property shall be held separate and apart from any other tangible personal property, and shall not be changed in form or altered in any way. 
(h)  Every pawnbroker shall provide the police department, on a weekly basis, with two copies of the records, on a form to be provided or approved by the police department, of all tangible personal property accepted during the preceding week and one copy of the customer's declaration of ownership. The form shall contain the same information required to be recorded in the pawnbroker's register pursuant to subsection (a). The police department shall designate the day of the week on which the records and declarations shall be submitted. 
(i)  Every pawnbroker shall clear, through the police department, prior to release, all firearms, other than those which are newly manufactured and which have not been previously sold at retail. 
(j)  Every pawnbroker shall pay to the city a transaction fee for each transaction involving a contract for purchase or purchase transaction. A transaction is limited to three items of tangible personal property per transaction form, subject to the following regulations. The transaction fee shall be set by city council resolution. 
(1)  For the purposes of the imposition of said transaction fee, a parcel or bundle of articles offered as one item and purchased for one set price shall be considered to be one item of tangible personal property. Tangible personal property with any identifying marks, including, but not limited to, any identification number, serial number, model number, or inscription, shall be individually itemized. 
(2)  Individual components of a stereo or computer system, including, but not limited to, compact discs, records, tapes or other recorded media, shall be individually itemized. However, when a stereo or computer system is being offered as one item and purchased for one set price, only one transaction fee shall be imposed, and a detailed itemized description of the item's components shall be recorded on the pawnbroker's register and on the customer's declaration of ownership. 
(3)  All sums of money paid by the customer to the pawnbroker as transaction fees imposed by this article shall be and remain public money and the property of the city in the hands of such pawnbroker, who shall hold the same in trust for the sole use and benefit of the city until paid to the city, subject to the following regulations: 
a.  If a pawnbroker neglects or refuses to pay any transaction fee as required by this article, then the finance director shall make an estimate, based upon such information as may be available, of the amount of the transaction fees due for the period for which the pawnbroker is delinquent and shall add thereto a penalty equal to either the sum of $15.00 for such failure or ten percent thereof and interest on such delinquent transaction fee at the rate imposed under subsection (j)(3)d of this section, plus one-half percent per month from the date when due, not exceeding 18 percent annually in the aggregate. 
b.  Promptly thereafter, the finance director shall give to the delinquent pawnbroker written notice of such estimated transaction fee, penalty, and interest, which notice shall be sent by first-class mail directed to the last address of such pawnbroker on file with the office of the city clerk. Such estimate shall thereupon become a notice of deficiency. 
c.  The finance director is authorized to waive, for good cause shown, any penalty as provided in this section, and any interest imposed in excess of the rate determined pursuant to this section shall be deemed a penalty. 
d.  When interest is required or permitted to be charged under this article, the annual rate of interest shall be that rate of interest established by the state commissioner of banking pursuant to C.R.S.  39-21-110.5., as same may be amended from time to time. 
(k)  Every pawnbroker shall, at his or her expense, keep records or provide reports in such manner and by such methods as may be determined from time to time by the police department or the city clerk. 
(l)  Every pawnbroker shall videotape all transactions, including those which do not result in a contract for purchase or purchase transaction. The videotape shall be in a format approved by the police department and of such quality that it clearly displays an identifiable frontal image of the customer. Any such videotape shall be kept by the pawnbroker for a minimum of 90 days and shall be subject to police review. If the videotape contains photographic evidence, it shall be held for 180 days. 
(m)  Pawnbroker establishments may be open for business only between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. It shall be unlawful for a pawnbroker establishment to be open for business during any time other than the hours set forth herein. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-90. - Prohibited acts of pawnbroker in the course of doing business. 
(a)  No pawnbroker, employee, or agent of the pawnbroker shall enter into a contract for purchase or purchase transaction with any person under the age of 18 years or with any person under the influence of alcoholic beverages or any narcotic drug, stimulant or depressant or any person appearing to be in an abnormal mental state. 
(b)  No pawnbroker, employee, or agent of the pawnbroker shall enter into a contract for purchase or purchase transaction with any person known by such persons to have been convicted of any felony without first notifying the police department, or with any person whose actions would give the pawnbroker, employee or agent of the pawnbroker probable cause to believe the tangible personal property that is the subject of the contract for purchase or purchase transaction was obtained illegally. 
(c)  With respect to a contract for purchase, no pawnbroker, employee, or agent of a pawnbroker may permit any customer to become obligated on the same day in any way under more than one contract for purchase agreement with the pawnbroker which would result in the pawnbroker obtaining a greater amount of money than would be permitted if the pawnbroker and customer had entered into only one contract for purchase covering the same tangible personal property. 
(d)  No pawnbroker, employee, or agent of the pawnbroker shall violate the terms of the contract for purchase. 
(e)  No pawnbroker, employee, or agent of the pawnbroker shall enter into a contract for purchase or purchase transaction for any tangible personal property wherein the identification number, serial number, model number, brand name, owner's identification number or other identifying marks on such property have been totally or partially obscured. For the purposes of this subsection the term "identification number" means a serial or model number placed by the manufacturer or owner upon an article as a permanent individual identifying mark, and "obscure" means to destroy, remove, alter, conceal or deface so as to render illegible by ordinary means of inspection. 
(f)  No pawnbroker, employee, or agent of the pawnbroker shall enter into a contract for purchase or purchase transaction when the property, which is the subject of the contract for purchase or purchase transaction, is other than tangible property. 
(g)  No pawnbroker, employee, or agent of the pawnbroker shall ask, demand or receive any greater rate of interest, commission and compensation than the total rate of one-fifth of the original purchase price for each month, plus the original purchase price. No other charges shall be made by the pawnbroker upon renewal of any contract for purchase or at any other time. In the event any such charges are made, the contract shall be void. Any contract for the payment of commissions by the customer for making a contract for purchase of tangible personal property shall be null and void. 
(h)  The violation of this section by an agent or employee of a pawnbroker shall be deemed to be a violation of this section by the pawnbroker. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-91. - Unlawful to pawn certain items. 
    It is unlawful for any pawnbroker, employee, or agent of the pawnbroker, to accept in pledge, buy, sell, or display in his place of business any switchblade knife, any knife whose blade is detachable from its handle, any knife whose blade opens by any mechanical means, any gravity knife, any throwing star, any brass or metallic knuckles or other items commonly used for and designed for the purpose of beating or striking others, any nunchaku, blackjack, or billy club, property with missing or altered serial numbers, or any computer or other electronic device where a required password is unknown, or any other property which is illegal to possess under local, state or federal law. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-92. - Hold orders and surrender of property. 
(a)  Any police officer may order a pawnbroker to hold any tangible personal property deposited with or in the custody of any pawnbroker for purposes of further investigation. A hold order shall be effective upon verbal notification to the pawnbroker by the police department for a period of 90 days and may, for good cause shown by the police department, be extended for an additional 90-day period. No sale or other imposition may be made of such property held by any pawnbroker while the hold order remains outstanding. A hold order shall supersede all other provisions of this article, and any sale or other disposition of the property after the pawnbroker has been notified by the police department of a hold order shall be unlawful and a violation of this section. 
(b)  If any police officer determines that any article of personal property held by a pawnbroker is stolen or illegally obtained property, such officer may immediately confiscate such property and must provide the pawnbroker with a receipt, case report number, and the police report cover sheet setting forth the basis for the confiscation. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-93. - Liability of pawnbroker. 
(a)  A pawnbroker who accepts any article in a purchase or contract of purchase transaction from a customer who is not the owner thereof obtains no title in the article either by reason of the expiration of the contract or by transfer of the receipt to the pawnbroker by the customer or holder thereof. Ignorance of the fact that the article was lost or stolen shall not be construed to affect the question of the title. If the pawnbroker shall sell such article to a third person, the pawnbroker shall recover the article or reimburse the lawful owner the fair market value of the article. The lawful owner may, upon proof of his or her ownership of the article lost or stolen, claim the same from the pawnbroker or recover the same by the appropriate legal means including, without limitation, forfeiture of the fair market value of such article out of the bond required by section 22-82. 
(b)  A pawnbroker shall be liable for the loss of tangible personal property or part thereof or for damages thereto, whether caused by fire, theft, burglary or otherwise, resulting from his or her failure to exercise reasonable care in regard to it. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-94. - Pawn tickets. 
(a)  At the time of making a contract for purchase, or upon the subsequent renewal of any contract for purchase, the pawnbroker shall deliver to the customer a pawn ticket containing stubs or duplicate copies which are correspondingly serially numbered, and which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the licensee; 
(2)  A description of the pledge sufficient to adequately identify the pledge; 
(3)  The date of the transaction; and 
(4)  The amount, duration, and terms of the contract for purchase. 
    In addition, language which complies with the requirements of section 22-89 of this article shall appear on the back of the pawn ticket. The pawnbroker may insert on the pawn ticket any other terms, conditions, and information not inconsistent with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Transfer of pawn ticket generally-Transfer to pawnbroker. The holder of the pawn ticket shall be presumed to be the person entitled to cancel the contract for purchase and, except as provided otherwise in this article, the pawnbroker shall deliver the pledge to the person presenting the pawn ticket upon payment of principal and any applicable charges, and upon surrender of the pawn ticket. The holder of any pawn ticket may transfer same to the issuing pawnbroker by writing upon the ticket "transferred to (name of pawnbroker)" and signing same under such writing. The effect of transferring a pawn ticket to the issuing pawnbroker shall be to vest in the pawnbroker such ownership and title to the pawn ticket and the pledged property represented thereby as the holder had. Every instance of transference of a pawn ticket to a pawnbroker shall be reported within seven days to the police department as set forth in section 22-89. 
(c)  Loss of pawn ticket . If a pawn ticket is lost, destroyed, or stolen, the customer shall so notify the issuing pawnbroker in writing. Before permitting the cancellation of the contract for purchase or issuing a duplicate pawn ticket, the pawnbroker may, in addition to satisfying himself/herself of the validity of the claim, require the customer to make an affidavit of the alleged loss, destruction, or theft of the ticket. Upon receipt of such affidavit or statement in writing, as the case may be, the pawnbroker shall permit the customer to cancel the contract for purchase or the pawnbroker shall deliver to the customer a duplicate ticket, and the pawnbroker shall incur no liability for doing so unless he/she had previously received written notice of an adverse claim. The form of the affidavit shall be substantially as follows: 
AFFIDAVIT OF LOSS OF PAWN TICKET STATE OF COLORADO ) ) SS: COUNTY OF ARAPAHOE )  
    I, being, first duly sworn, do depose and say: 
(1)  I am the pledgor of a pawn ticket issued by (name of pawnbroker), numbered ("Unknown" if number is not known), and dated ("Unknown" if date is not known). 
(2)  The above-described pawn ticket has not been sold, negotiated, or transferred in any other manner by me. 
(3)  The above-described pawn ticket was lost, destroyed, or stolen as follows: 
_____ 
_____ 
(4)  The pledge represented by this pawn ticket is (description of pledge) 
Further affiant sayeth not. 
_____ 
Affiant 
Subscribed and sworn to before me this __________ day of ______________/___________/____________, 20____________ ___________ 
Notary Public 
My Commission expires: _____ 
(d)  Adverse claims. If more than one person claims the right to cancel a contract for purchase, the pawnbroker shall incur no liability for refusing to deliver the pledge until the respective rights of the claimants are adjudicated. If no action is brought against the pawnbroker by either party prior to the expiration of the period for which the pawnbroker is required under section 22-89 of this article to hold the pledge, the pawnbroker may proceed to sell the pledge in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(e)  Altered pawn ticket. The alteration of a pawn ticket shall not excuse the pawnbroker who issued it from liability to deliver the pledge according to the terms of the ticket as originally issued, but shall relieve the pawnbroker from any other liability to the pledgor of the ticket. 
(f)  Seizure of counterfeit or reportedly lost pawn ticket-Seizure of counterfeit or fraudulent identification. 
(1)  If a ticket is presented to a pawnbroker which purports to be one issued by him/her but which is found to be counterfeit or, which has been reported to him/her as lost, stolen or destroyed, the pawnbroker may seize and retain the same without incurring any liability whatsoever to the holder thereof. Upon such occasion, the pawnbroker shall immediately notify the police department. The police department shall then place a hold order on the pawn ticket so seized, as set out in section 22-92, and the pledged property identified in said pawn ticket shall be held by the pawnbroker until such time as the lawful disposition of the pledged property is either agreed upon, determined by a court action, or directed by ordinance or statute, or until the hold order is either ordered released by the police department or has expired. 
(2)  If a pawnbroker has reason to believe a customer is exhibiting counterfeit or fraudulent identification, the pawnbroker or his/her employee, acting in good faith and upon probable cause based upon reasonable grounds therefor, may seize such identification without incurring civil or criminal liability as a result of such seizure, provided the pawnbroker immediately notifies and gives such identification to the police department. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Sec. 22-95. - Proximity. 
(a)  No pawnbroker business or facility shall be located on any site unless allowed as a permitted use in the underlying zone district, and not less than the distance limitations as required by this section: 
(1)  One thousand five hundred feet from the location of another pawnbroker business or facility; and 
(2)  One thousand feet from the boundary line of any residential district or use defined in the comprehensive zoning plan or as currently zoned within the city, or any religious institution, public park, public library, public or private school, community center or educational institution, child care or adult care use or facility, whether within or outside the city's boundaries. 
(b)  With respect to the distance from the boundary line of a residential district or any religious institution, public park, public library, community center or educational institution, the distance shall be measured by following a straight line from the nearest point of the property line of the proposed licensed premises to the nearest point of the district boundary line; or in the case of a religious institution, public park, public library, community center, public or private school, educational institution, or child or adult care use (which are collectively referred to as "protected uses"), the distance shall be measured by following a straight line from the nearest point of the property line of the proposed licensed premises to the nearest point of the property line of such protected use. 
( Ord. No. 1-2015,  9, 6-8-2015 ) 
Secs. 22-96-22-110. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VII. - TRASH HAULER'S LICENSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Provisions set out herein as art. XII,  12-251-12-263, have been redesignated as such by the editor. Ord. No. 1992-17,  1, adopted September 22, 1992, enacted such provisions as art. XI,  12-221-12-233. See also the editor's footnote to art. XI. 

Sec. 22-215. - Legislative findings and purpose. 
    The city council finds that trash, garbage, refuse and other solid wastes from residences and businesses within the city have been known to contribute to the consumption of limited landfill space and that solid waste landfills may also contribute to the pollution of air, water and other precious natural resources of the state. The city council finds that the best interests of the public's overall health, safety and welfare will be served by a program for the recycling and reuse of recyclable materials contained in the garbage, trash, refuse, and other solid wastes generated by residences and businesses within the city. The city council finds that the city should support such a recycling program by encouraging economic competition and free enterprise within the city among private trash haulers willing to provide recycling services. Moreover, city council finds that residents and business operators will more readily take advantage of available recycling services if the city facilitates the free flow of information concerning such services. 
(Code 1986,  12-251) 
Sec. 22-216. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, certain words and phrases herein are defined as follows: 
    Approved plan. A recycling program prescribing the method of collection and recycling of recyclable materials, which is proposed by a trash hauler and approved by the city clerk or the city clerk's designee in connection with the issuance of a trash hauler's license. 
    Customer. The owner, occupant or authorized representative of a separate residence, business or property within the city who contracts with a trash hauler for trash collection services or the removal of trash from said residence, business or property. 
    Participate in a recycling program. Agreement by a customer to collect recyclable material and dispose of said materials with a trash hauler in substantial accordance with the trash hauler's approved plan. 
    Recyclable material. Any reusable materials, including but not limited to, aluminum, glass, plastic and paper, which are capable of or intended for re-use, remanufacture or reconstitution. Recyclable material does not include toxic or hazardous materials. 
    Recycling program. A program approved by the city clerk or the city clerk's designee pursuant to which a trash hauler collects recyclable material from its customers and disposes of such materials in a manner consistent with the approved plan. 
    Trash. Any tangible personal property, including, without limitation, garbage, refuse or rubble, which has been discarded by its former owner for collection by a trash hauler. 
    Trash hauler. Any person who or which for any compensation, and on a regular or scheduled basis, removed trash from any residence, property or business in the city. The term "trash hauler" shall not include a person who delivers recyclable material owned by the person to a recycling center or drop off facility and receives compensation therefor. 
(Code 1986,  12-252) 
Sec. 22-217. - Unlawful acts. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in business as a trash hauler within the city without first having obtained a trash hauler's license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1986,  12-253) 
Sec. 22-218. - Application, form and contents. 
    An application for a trash hauler's license shall be on a form to be furnished by the city, shall be filed with the city clerk or the city clerk's designee, shall be accompanied by the applicable license fee as established by resolution of the city council, a certificate of insurance establishing general liability coverage in a minimum amount of $1,000,000.00, together with a certificate of insurance establishing that the applicant and employees are covered under the state worker's compensation insurance program. All applications shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and business address of each such applicant, the telephone number, and emergency or mobile telephone number, if available; 
(2)  If the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the names and residence address of each of the partners of such partnership, or the name and residence address of each of the officers and directors of the corporation, and the address of its principal place of business; 
(3)  A statement of the applicant's experience as a trash hauler, and a listing of any licenses presently held by the applicant for other Colorado municipalities; 
(4)  The applicant's plan for collection and recycling of recyclable materials, including: 
a.  The types of recyclable materials which will be collected; 
b.  The proposed method of sorting the recyclable materials; 
c.  The designated days of collection of recyclable materials (which shall not be less often than two days per month for each customer) as compared with the designated day or days of collection of trash other than recyclable materials; 
d.  The proposed plan for educating the applicant's customers concerning recycling and its benefits; 
e.  The proposed plan for educating the applicant's customers concerning toxic or hazardous materials and the proper disposal of such materials; 
f.  The proposed method of encouraging the applicant's customers to recycle; 
g.  The proposed method of disposing of collected recyclable materials in a manner that will maximize the reuse of said materials; 
h.  The proposed plan for collecting and disposing of toxic or hazardous materials; 
i.  The proposed time schedule for implementing the recycling program; 
j.  The proposed method of monitoring customer participation in the recycling program; and for all renewal applicants, the percent of the applicant's customers who are participating in a recycling program; 
k.  Declare enforcement actions by state or federal agencies for violations of law. 
(5)  A guarantee that all collected recyclable materials will be disposed of in accordance with the recycling program submitted with the application, in a manner which will maximize the reuse of said materials; and 
(6)  An explanation of any pending enforcement or monitoring action taken by any state or federal agency against the applicant, any pending litigation involving the applicant, and any past enforcement, monitoring or litigation that occurred within the two years immediately prior to application and each subsequent renewal period. 
(Code 1986,  12-254) 
Sec. 22-219. - Review of application by city clerk. 
    The city clerk or the city clerk's designee shall review each application to determine that it has been fully completed and is in compliance with the requirements of this Code and the rules and regulations promulgated by the city pursuant to this article. The city clerk or the city clerk's designee may request additional information from the applicant or impose additional requirements and conditions consistent with this Code and rules and regulations promulgated by the city, for inclusion in the applicant's plan. 
(Code 1986,  12-255) 
Sec. 22-220. - License, issuance. 
(a)  Within 30 days after receipt of an application and the payment of the license fee, the city clerk or the city clerk designee shall either approve the application and issue a trash hauler's license to the applicant; or approve the application subject to additional requirements and conditions which must be met before a license will be issued; or deny the application setting forth the reasons for denial. 
(b)  Every trash hauler's license shall be subject to the provisions of the trash hauler's recycling plan approved by the city clerk or the city clerk's designee, or by the city, as appropriate. 
(Code 1986,  12-256) 
Sec. 22-221. - Appeal. 
    In the event the city clerk or the city clerk's designee denies an application for a trash hauler's license, the applicant may within 15 days following the denial, file a written statement appealing the decision of the city clerk or the city clerk's designee to the city manager. The city manager shall review all applicable evidence to determine whether a trash hauler's license should be issued to the applicant. The city manager shall issue a decision within 15 days of the date that the city clerk or the city clerk's designee issued the decision denying the application. 
(Code 1986,  12-257) 
Sec. 22-222. - Recycling program. 
    Every trash hauler within the city shall provide a copy of its recycling program to any city resident or business which requests a copy of such program. 
(Code 1986,  12-258) 
Sec. 22-223. - Notice of charges. 
    In the event a trash hauler charges more for its services to customers who participate in a recycling program than to customers who do not participate in a recycling program, the trash hauler shall notify its customers of this fact by written notice, included with a billing statement or by other notice, which contains the following information: 
(1)  The monthly or quarterly charges of the trash hauler for each of its services, including recycling services and nonrecycling services; 
(2)  A clear identification that the trash hauler charges more for recycling; and 
(3)  The words "For more information concerning licensed haulers, call the City of Sheridan at (303)762-2200." 
(Code 1986,  12-259) 
Sec. 22-224. - License suspension and revocation. 
(a)  The city clerk or the city clerk's designee may, after notice and hearing, suspend or revoke a trash hauler's license for a violation of any of the provisions of this article, a violation of the trash hauler's approved plan, or for providing false or fraudulent information in a trash hauler's application. 
(b)  Any applicant or licensee aggrieved by any decision of the city clerk or the city clerk's designee may appeal from such decision to the city manager in the manner prescribed in section 22-221. 
(Code 1986,  12-260) 
Sec. 22-225. - Expiration and renewal of license. 
    A trash hauler's license issued pursuant to this article shall expire one year from the date the license was issued. A trash hauler's license may be renewed by submission of an application to the city clerk or the city clerk's designee which application shall include any proposed amendments or revisions to the trash hauler's approved plan and any other information required in rules and regulations adopted by the city and which shall be accompanied by the license renewal fee as established by city council. The city clerk or the city clerk's designee shall review the completed renewal application and shall act on it in accordance with the provisions of this article concerning the issuance of said licenses. The city clerk or the city clerk's designee may establish additional requirements and conditions on the renewal of a trash hauler's license consistent with this Code and rules and regulations promulgated by the city. 
(Code 1986,  12-261) 
Sec. 22-226. - Antiscavenging. 
    No person shall, without the written permission of the owner of recyclable material, take recyclable material which has been set out by a customer in receptacles which contain only recyclable material, for collection by a trash hauler; or remove any recyclable materials from a container, box, collection, vehicle, depot or other receptacle for the accumulation or storage of recyclable material. 
(Code 1986,  12-262) 
Sec. 22-227. - License fees. 
(a)  Each trash hauler shall upon the submission of its application and proposed recycling program pay, for each truck used within the city, a license fee in an amount set by resolution of city council. 
(b)  Each trash hauler shall upon submission of its renewal application pay, for each truck used within the city, a license renewal fee in an amount set by resolution of city council. 
(c)  The city clerk or the city clerk's designee shall not issue or renew a trash hauler's license until the applicant has paid the appropriate fee in full. 
(Code 1986,  12-263) 
Sec. 22-228. - Exclusion. 
    The service provider under contract with the city to provide residential waste service collection services, as set forth in Article VII.5 of this chapter shall be exempt from any rule, regulation or requirement of this article during the pendency of its contract with the city. 
( Ord. No. 8-2014,  1, 5-27-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-229. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII.5. - RESIDENTIAL WASTE SERVICE COLLECTION 

Sec. 22-230. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall, unless otherwise specified apply only to the service provider(s) currently under contract with the city to provide residential waste service collection. 
( Ord. No. 8-2014,  2, 5-27-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-231. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall mean as follows, unless specifically designated otherwise. 
    Excluded waste means all commercial and industrial refuse, construction debris, large dead animals, institutional solid waste, hazardous waste, offal waste, stable matter, and special waste, highly flammable substances, liquid waste, certain pathological and biological waste, explosives, toxic materials, radioactive materials, material that the disposal facility is not authorized to receive and/or dispose of, and other materials deemed by state, federal or local law, or in the reasonable discretion of the city's residential waste collector, to be dangerous or threatening to health or the environment, or which cannot be legally accepted at the disposal facility. 
    Garbage means all small dead animals, every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable and/or other matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing in, handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains or other animal or vegetable matter (including, but not by way of limitation, used tin cans and other food containers); and all putrescible or easily decomposable waste, animal or vegetable matter, which is likely to attract flies or rodents; except (in all cases) any matter included in the definition of excluded waste. 
    Recyclable materials means those goods or items deemed by the city as single stream recyclables collected and transported in accordance with the city's residential waste collection services program. 
    Residential waste means garbage, refuse, or rubbish, as such terms are defined herein, which are generated from residential sources and other discarded goods subject to collection in accordance with the city's residential waste collection services program. 
    Residential waste collection services means the collection and transportation of residential waste and recyclable materials by the city's designated service provider(s) from participants in the city's residential waste collection services program. 
    Refuse means all nonhazardous, solid waste (including garbage, rubbish, and yard waste) generated at a residential unit that is not excluded by this article. "Refuse" shall not include any excluded waste. 
    Rubbish means all waste wood, wood chips, shavings, sawdust, printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and discarded mattresses, used and discarded clothing, used and discarded shoes and boots, combustible waste pulp and other products such as are used for packaging, or wrapping crockery and glass, ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, glass, mineral or metallic substances, and any and all other waste materials not included in the definition of excluded waste. 
    Small dead animals means animals or potions thereof less than ten pounds in weight that have expired from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human use. 
    Waste and recycling containers means, for those persons subject to the city's residential waste collection services program, a wheeled cart suitable for mechanical lifting with a lid for containment and setting out waste or recycling for collection in sizes of approximately 32 gallons, 64 gallons, and/or 96 gallons, or such other standard size container as staff deems appropriate. 
( Ord. No. 8-2014,  2, 5-27-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-232. - Recyclable materials-Handling and collection requirements. 
(a)  All recyclable materials shall be drained of liquid before being deposited for collection. 
(b)  Recycling containers shall be provided by the city or its designated residential waste collection service provider. Such containers shall be used only for collection of recyclable materials. 
(c)  No person shall place, leave, deposit or dispose of any recyclable materials on any street, alley or other public place, or on any private property, unless the materials are wholly contained within a recycling container. Any accumulation, placement or disposal of recyclable materials in violation of this article is declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. 
(d)  Recycling containers shall be kept off the street, curb, sidewalk and all other public ways, except on the scheduled day of collection, and then only for a maximum of 12 hours before and 12 hours after the scheduled time of collection. 
( Ord. No. 8-2014,  2, 5-27-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-233. - Waste and recycling responsibility. 
    Waste and recyclable materials shall be gathered, deposited, disposed of and placed in the manner provided for in this article by the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of the property, or the agent or contractor of any of the foregoing, and each of the foregoing persons may be held jointly and severally liable for any violation of this article. 
( Ord. No. 8-2014,  2, 5-27-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-234. - City residential waste and recyclable materials collection services. 
(a)  The city's designated residential waste collection service provider(s) shall furnish residential waste collection services as provided in this article for all residents within the city, except those specifically excluded as set forth in section 22-235 below. 
(b)  All waste and recyclable materials shall be placed in waste and recyclable containers by the owner, tenant, or occupant of each residence. Containers shall be placed in the street adjacent to each residence on a schedule as established by the city. 
(c)  Bulky items, which are those too large to fit in the residential waste container, shall be removed by private arrangement with the city's residential waste collection services provider(s) or another licensed provider authorized to haul waste or recyclables within the city, or by the resident. Neither the city, nor its designated residential waste collection service provider(s), or licensed operators, shall have any obligation to collect or transport any waste or recyclables not in a proper container, or any containers not properly placed for collection. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to set out or allow to be set out, deposited, or stored for collection, any waste or recyclable materials other than that which has accumulated from the regular residential use of the premises upon which such waste or recyclables are set out, deposited, or stored for collection. 
( Ord. No. 8-2014,  2, 5-27-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-235. - Premises excluded from services. 
    All commercial and industrial establishments and multifamily residences containing eight or more units are excluded from the city's residential waste collection services program. 
( Ord. No. 8-2014,  2, 5-27-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-236. - Residential waste and recyclable hauling. 
    Nothing in this article shall prohibit any person from contracting for or hauling one's own waste and recyclable materials, providing it is collected and disposed of in conformity with all applicable city ordinances, rules and regulations. 
( Ord. No. 8-2014,  2, 5-27-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-237. - Residential waste collection services fee. 
    City council shall, by resolution, establish the fee to be imposed for residential waste collection services. The fee shall be imposed on all city residences not excluded from residential waste collection services, pursuant to section 22-235 above, regardless of whether the city's residential waste collection services are actually utilized by such residence. The fee shall be billed to residents and collected by the city's contractual residential waste hauler. 
( Ord. No. 8-2014,  2, 5-27-2014 ) 
Secs. 22-238-22-247. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RESERVED 

Secs. 22-248-22-284. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1-2015 ,  13, adopted June 8, 2015, repealed Art. VIII,  22-248-22-253, which pertained to residential group homes for children. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
ARTICLE IX. - BUILDING TRADES REGULATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Electricians, C.R.S.  12-23-100.2 et seq.; plumbers, C.R.S.  12-58-101 et seq. 

Sec. 22-285. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building official means the city chief building official or the chief's designee. 
    Contractor. 
(1)  The term "contractor" means any person who undertakes work with or for another person to build, construct, alter, remodel, repair, equip, move or demolish any building or structure, or any portion thereof, or any public utility system, or public street, for which a permit from the city is required and which work is to be accomplished for any form of compensation; and specifically includes, but is not limited to, persons who perform construction, remodeling, demolition, grading and excavating services. 
(2)  The term "contractor" does not include a homeowner who builds, constructs, alters, repairs, adds to, moves, or wrecks any building or structure, or any portion thereof that constitutes the owner's residence or a building or structure accessory thereto, that is intended for the owner's personal use. 
(3)  The term "qualified supervisor" means any person who has passed the International Code Conference ("ICC") examination for construction supervisors. 
(Code 1986,  12-400; Ord. No. 11-2014,  1, 7-14-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-286. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any contractor to perform work within the city without first having obtained a license therefor from the building official. 
(Code 1986,  12-401) 
Sec. 22-286.5. - Supervision required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any contractor to cause or permit any work to be performed on a commercial project without the on-site presence of a qualified supervisor. 
( Ord. No. 11-2014,  2, 7-14-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-287. - License application. 
    Applicants shall submit a written application to the building official that includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The applicant's name, address and telephone number. If the applicant is a corporation, evidence that the applicant is in good standing to conduct business within the state. 
(2)  A certificate of insurance from an agent or insurance company demonstrating that the applicant has workers' compensation insurance in the statutorily required amounts, general commercial or liability insurance with minimum limits of not less than $100,000.00 each occurrence and $300,000.00 general aggregate, and automobile liability insurance with minimum combined single limits for bodily injury and property damage of not less than $300,000.00 for any occurrence. Such certificate shall also include an endorsement requiring that the building official be notified within ten days of any such policy's cancellation or nonrenewal. 
(3)  A listing of all other current contractor licenses or registrations for governmental entities in the State of Colorado and whether or not the applicant, has in the last five years, had any contractor license or registration denied, revoked, suspended or not renewed. 
(4)  Applicants for class A, B, C, D, masonry, mechanical-ventilation-AC (HVAC), concrete form, and trade contractor licenses must demonstrate competence through passage of an examination administered by the ICC or submittal of proof of current registration, or license of the same, or equivalent license classification, from a governmental entity that requires ICC testing as part of its registration or licensing process. 
(5)  Each application shall include a nonrefundable application fee. 
(Code 1986,  12-402; Ord. No. 7-2010,  1, 6-30-2010; Ord. No. 11-2014,  3, 7-14-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-288. - Issuance or denial. 
(a)  Within 15 days of receipt of a complete application, the building official shall either issue or deny an application. If an application is denied, the building official shall send the applicant written notice of the denial setting forth the grounds for denial. The building official shall issue a license unless one or more of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  The applicant has had any contractor's license or registration denied, revoked, suspended or not renewed within the last five years; or 
(2)  The applicant has failed to comply with the city's ordinances, codes, rules or regulations pertaining to any contractor activities or duties regulated by this article; or 
(3)  The applicant is delinquent in any fees, taxes, penalties or interest due the city, or 
(4)  The applicant has failed to demonstrate the required competency as determined by the building official. 
(b)  An applicant may appeal a denial by the building official by providing a written notice of appeal and grounds therefor to the city manager within ten days of the building officials decision. Based upon the record and information provided in the appeal, the city manager shall, based upon a preponderance of the evidence either uphold or overturn the building official's decision. The city manager's decision shall be provided in writing to the applicant within 15 days of submittal of an appeal. 
(Code 1986,  12-403) 
Sec. 22-289. - Fees. 
(a)  In addition to a nonrefundable application fee, a licensee shall pay an annual license fee due at the time of issuance or renewal of a license. 
(b)  All fees shall be established by resolution of council. 
(c)  Electricians and plumbers licensed by the state shall be exempt from all fees set forth in this article. 
(Code 1986,  12-404) 
Sec. 22-290. - Renewal. 
    All licenses shall expire 12 months from the date of issuance, unless otherwise cancelled, suspended or revoked and may be renewed annually upon application, payment of all fees and fulfillment of all terms and conditions set forth in this article. 
(Code 1986,  12-405) 
Sec. 22-291. - Classification of licenses. 
(a)  Class A. This license entitles the holder to construct, alter, finish or repair any type or size of structure permitted by the city's building code. 
(b)  Class B. This license entitles the holder to construct, alter or repair any structures five stories or less permitted by the city's building code. 
(c)  Class C. This license entitles the holder to construct, alter or repair any multi-family structures (three or more units) three stories or less permitted by the city's building code. 
(d)  Class D. This license entitles the holder to construct, alter or repair any single-family home or duplexes permitted by the city's building code.
