Information regarding the operator's compliance with all other applicable laws by certifying that the operator has obtained the appropriate federal or state permits, licenses and approvals, or by identifying all federal, state or local permits, licenses or approval for which the operators or owners have applied but have not, as yet, obtained including the type of permit, license or approval (local building permits, local fence permits, local business licenses, state health department approvals, federal Environmental Protection Agency permits or approvals, et cetera); the dates that the owner or operator applied for each permit, license or approval; and the status of such application or the expected approval date for each pending permit, license or approval; 
j.  The application shall also include a bond in the amount of $100,000.00 made payable to the people of the City of Sheridan for use by the city in the event that the applicant's operations create any threat to the health, safety or general welfare of the people of the city that the city must remedy or mitigate at public expense. Such bond may be limited for use by the city only when the applicant's operations, or the closing of such operations, or the bankruptcy or financial position of the operator or owner, results in circumstances that threaten public health, safety or welfare and the applicant either lacks the financial ability to remedy or mitigate those circumstances, or simply fails to remedy or mitigate those circumstances expeditiously. The city's use of the bond pursuant to this subsection shall not prevent the city from pursuing such other legal, equitable or criminal remedies as otherwise provided by law. Moreover, if the city must use the bond pursuant to this subsection, and if the purchaser of such bond remains in business after the use of the bond by the city, such operator must acquire and present to the city another bond which satisfies the terms of this subsection within three business days. All bonds must be reviewed and approved by the city attorney before the operator may receive a permit pursuant to subsection (d) of this section. 
(d)  Permit approval. 
(1)  An applicant for a permit under this section shall submit two copies of its Colorado Department of Health application, the supplemental information required by subsection (c)(2) of this section, and the application fee, to the building official for the city. The building official shall forward one copy of the application to the chief of the city's fire department. 
(2)  The building official and the fire chief shall each initially review such application and either or both may request such additional information from the applicant as either or both the building official or fire chief reasonably deem appropriate. After the applicant has satisfied the building official's and the fire chief's requests for additional information, if any, and paid the application fee, the building official and fire chief shall jointly forward the copies of such application and the supplemental information to the planning commission with their respective recommendations. 
(3)  The planning commission shall schedule such application for a public hearing and publish a public notice of such hearing at least ten days prior to the hearing date. The applicant shall also post the property at the applicant's expense, according to current city zoning ordinance standards, at least 15 days prior to the public hearing as directed by the building official. The posted sign shall contain the property's legal description, its proposed use, and the date, time and place of the public hearing. 
a.  Any person shall be allowed to review any application which is the subject of pending approval hearing by scheduling an appointment with the building official during the regular business hours of the city. 
b.  After such review, any person may order a photocopy of the application from the building official by making a $20.00 deposit for photocopying expenses. The building official shall prepare the photocopy of the application and have such ordered copy available within three business days. The person ordering such photocopies shall pay the balance of the photocopying costs upon delivery of the copy by the building official. 
(4)  The planning commission shall hold a public hearing on the noticed date and determine if any community opposition or approval exists for the proposed waste transfer station and to elicit any public input on items which may have been overlooked in the application which could have an adverse impact on the public. The planning commission may request that the applicant submit additional information or continue such public hearing so that the commission may more fully evaluate the application. 
(5)  Within 30 calendar days following its final public hearing, the planning commission shall forward the application to city council, along with its recommendations. The planning commission may recommend the application for approval, approval only with additional restrictions or conditions, or denial. If the planning commission recommends approval with conditions or denial of the application, the planning commission shall also submit to council a written report stating the reasons for its recommended conditions or restrictions, or the reasons for its recommended denial. 
(6)  Within 30 calendar days following the receipt by council of the planning commission's recommendations, city council shall take action approving or disapproving the waste transfer station, or scheduling the matter for additional public hearings if questions still exist. Council may adopt the recommendation of the planning commission, or may reject the recommendation of the planning commission. Moreover, council may approve the waste transfer station with or without conditions or restrictions reasonably calculated to protect the health, safety or general welfare of the public in addition to those recommended by the planning commission. 
(7)  The building official shall forward to the applicant the final action of council within five business days. 
(e)  Permit renewal. 
(1)  After a person has received a permit to operate a waste transfer station within the city, such permit shall be valid for not more than 12 months. Such permit must be renewed on or before January 31st of the next year following the year in which the preceding permit was issued. The application for renewal may adopt the original permit application by reference and shall supplement such original application with any new or changed information regarding the personnel or operations of the facility. 
(2)  The applicant shall submit a renewal application to the building official along with the applicable renewal fee. The building official shall forward the renewal application to city council which may renew the permit by resolution if the renewal application indicates that the waste transfer station has not changed materially either in operation or personnel such that no new or additional risks to the health, safety or general welfare of the public appear to exist. 
(3)  If the building official has reason to believe that the operator has violated the conditions of its previous permit, has otherwise violated the law in its operation of the waste transfer station, or has falsely or fraudulently submitted any information to any city department, agency, commission or board, the building official may recommend to city council that it refuse to renew the permit and that the city council issue a notice to show cause pursuant to subsection (f) of this section. Under such circumstances, the city council shall consider the renewal application as a permit revocation or suspension matter pursuant to subsection (f) of this section. 
(f)  Permit suspension or revocation. 
(1)  If the building official has reason to believe that the operator has violated the conditions of its permit, has otherwise violated the law in its operation of the waste transfer station, has allowed nuisance conditions to develop or exist at the site, or has falsely or fraudulently submitted any information to any city department, agency, commission or board, the building official may ask the city council to issue a notice to show cause to the operator of the waste transfer station. 
(2)  Upon recommendation of the building official, or upon its own motion, the city council may issue a notice to show cause to the operator. The notice to show cause shall inform the operator that the city council has scheduled a public hearing concerning the operator's permit and at such hearing the operator may appear and show cause why such permit should not be suspended or revoked. The notice to show cause shall briefly state the grounds alleged for suspending or revoking the operator's permit, and the date, time and location of the public hearing. The notice to show cause shall be published and posted pursuant to subsection (d)(3). 
(3)  At the public hearing to show cause, the city may present evidence to support the allegations of the show cause notice. The operator may represent himself or may be represented by legal counsel at the show cause hearing. The operator may cross examine any witness presented by the city and may present evidence to rebut the allegations made by the building official. The city may cross examine the witnesses presented by the operator. The mayor, or his designee, shall serve as the hearing officer at such public hearing and shall rule on all evidentiary mattes. The hearing officer shall endeavor to employ procedures which fairly allow both the city and the operator to present their respective cases, but shall not be bound by the formal rules of evidence. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded electronically or by a certified shorthand reporter. 
(4)  At the conclusion of the public hearing, the city council may go into executive session to deliberate on the evidence presented. Within 30 days following the conclusion of the public hearing, city council shall make its written findings and order. The city council may revoke the operator's permit, suspend the operator's permit, or impose additional conditions on the operator's permit. In the event that council decides to suspend or revoke the operator's permit, the operator shall immediately implement the alternative operations plan for processing the waste stream and/or for closure of the facility pursuant to the application for approval by the Colorado Department of Health. 
(g)  Permit fees. 
(1)  The building official shall not take any action on any original application for a permit until the applicant has paid an application fee in the amount of $5,000.00 to defray the city's expenses in considering and processing such application, and in inspecting and enforcing operators' compliance with such permits. 
(2)  The building official shall not take any action on any application for the renewal of a permit until the applicant has paid a renewal fee in the amount of $1,000.00 to defray the city's expenses in considering and processing such application, and in the ongoing inspection and enforcement of operators' compliance with such permits. 
(3)  Application and renewal fees shall not be refunded to applicants in the event the applicant's application for a permit is denied, not renewed, revoked or suspended. 
(h)  Restrictions on accessory uses. In addition to the application requirements and permit conditions, with which the operators of waste transfer stations must comply, operators must also satisfy the requirements of this subsection. 
(1)  Scavenging. Scavenging shall be prohibited at waste transfer stations and operators shall post "No Trespassing" signs in conspicuous places at the site as directed or approved by the city to discourage scavenging; operators shall take reasonable security measures to prevent scavenging, including the installation of fencing and adequate locks where appropriate; and operators shall undertake such other reasonable security measure as required by the city. 
(2)  Parking. Unclean transfer vehicles containing putrescible material shall not be parked on public streets or roadways; transfer or other facility vehicles shall be parked in adequate off-street and on-site parking spaces; unclean and other facility vehicles shall be parked separately from parking areas used by, or accessible to, the general public; vehicles shall be washed or cleaned at a commercial truck wash facility and shall not be cleaned or washed on-site. 
(3)  Waste handling. Receptacles containing infectious wastes shall be clearly labeled with the biohazard symbol or with the words "Infectious Waste" printed in letters of no less than one inch in height; infectious wastes must be stored, packaged, contained and transported in a manner that prevent the spilling, leaking or release of any waste material; treated infectious wastes that are no longer infectious may be mixed with other noninfectious wastes for transportation; contaminated sharps shall be placed in puncture-resistant containers; all other permitted wastes and potentially hazardous materials shall be appropriately labeled pursuant to state or federal regulations. No untreated wastes shall be stored at the facility for more than two weeks without the permission of the building official. 
(4)  Reporting. Spills, leakages or releases of infectious wastes shall be immediately cleaned up by the transporter and verbally reported to the city and other appropriate governmental entities as soon as reasonably possible after the incident; written reports regarding any spills, leakages or releases of infectious wastes shall be delivered to the city and other appropriate governmental entities within seven days. 
(5)  Miscellaneous. Certain types of accessory facilities or operations must also satisfy the following standards and obtain the following approvals: 
a.  Recycling. Recovery of materials such as metals, paper and glass shall be permitted when performed in a controlled and organized manner, subject to approval of the city, provided that: 
1.  Recycling operations shall be confined to specified, clearly defined areas of the facility; 
2.  Recovered materials shall be stored in areas separated from other activity areas; 
3.  Such recycling and storage activities shall be conducted in limited access areas which preclude access by persons other than employees or the operator; and 
4.  Recovered materials shall be stored in limited quantities or volumes, to be approved by the city, so that such materials shall not attract rodents, flies or insects, create a fire hazard, or otherwise create a nuisance. 
b.  Volume reduction. Volume reduction operations, such as bailing or shredding, are permitted at transfer and/or recycling facilities, provided that: 
1.  Such activities shall be confined to specified, clearly defined areas of the facility and be conducted in a controlled manner as an integral part of the entire operation; 
2.  Such activities are conducted in limited access areas which preclude access by persons other than employees or the operator; and 
3.  Recovered materials shall be stored in limited quantities or volumes, to be approved by the city, so that such material shall not attract rodents, flies or insects, create a fire hazard, or otherwise create a nuisance. 
c.  Nonsalvageable items. Nonsalvageable items such as drugs, cosmetics, foods, beverages, hazardous chemicals, poisons, medical wastes, infectious wastes, pesticides, and similar materials capable of impairing public health shall not be salvaged unless approved by the city. 
d.  Standards supplemental. The minimal operational, engineering and design standards specified in this section shall supplement the applicable federal and state statutes and regulations, and the applicable city ordinances. Compliance with these standards shall not exempt operators from land use, zoning, building code, fire code, or other public health, safety and general welfare regulations controlling the approved operations or facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009) 
Secs. 56-364-56-380. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - F-FLOODPLAIN OVERLAY DISTRICT 

Sec. 56-381. - Floodplain overlay district findings, boundaries, intent. 
(a)  Findings . 
(1)  The Legislature of the State of Colorado has in C.R.S.  31-15-103, as amended, delegated the responsibility to local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of its citizenry. 
(2)  The city council finds that there are, within the city, flood hazard areas which are subject to periodic inundation resulting in potential loss of life and property, danger to health and safety, disruption of commerce and government services, extraordinary public expenditure for flood protection and relief and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(3)  These flood losses are caused by the cumulative effect of obstructions in areas of special flood hazards which increase flood heights and velocities, and some of which, when inadequately anchored, cause damage to uses in other areas. Flood losses are also caused by uses that are inadequately floodproofed, inadequately elevated or otherwise not protected from flood damage. 
(b)  Boundaries . 
(1)  This district shall encompass the one-hundred-year floodplain, as it graphically appears or is noted on the duly adopted floodplain map. 
(2)  The floodplain district shall overlay that portion of any other district, including any planned unit development district, located in the floodplain. The regulations of this district shall be construed as being supplementary to the regulations imposed on the same lands by any underlying district. When regulations of this district conflict with any provisions of the underlying district, the provisions of this district shall control. Any underlying district shall remain in full force and effect to the extent that its provisions do not conflict with the provisions of this district. 
(c)  It is the purpose of this section to promote the public health, safety and welfare and to reduce the flood hazards described above. To accomplish its purposes, this floodplain overlay district includes provisions for: 
(1)  Reducing the hazards of flood to life and property by: 
a.  Restricting or prohibiting uses which are dangerous to life or property in time of flood; 
b.  Restricting or prohibiting uses which would be hazardous to the public health in time of flood; 
c.  Restricting uses which are particularly susceptible to flood damage; 
d.  Requiring permitted floodplain uses, including public facilities which serve such uses, to be protected against floods by providing floodproofing and general flood protection at the time of initial construction; 
e.  Minimizing the need for, and expense of, rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding; 
f.  Minimizing prolonged business interruptions as a result of flooding; 
g.  Minimizing damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, and streets and bridges located in areas of special flood hazard; 
h.  Helping maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of areas of special flood hazard so as to minimize future flood blight areas; 
i.  Ensuring that potential buyers are notified that property is in an area of special flood hazard; 
j.  Ensuring that those who occupy the areas of special flood hazards assume responsibility for their actions; and 
k.  Preventing or regulating the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert flood waters or which may increase flood hazards in other areas. 
(2)  Protecting floodplain occupants from floods caused by their own, or other, land uses which were or may have been undertaken without full realization of the danger, by: 
a.  Regulating the manner in which structures designed for human occupancy may be constructed so as to prevent danger to human life within such structures; 
b.  Regulating the method of construction of water supply and sanitation systems so as to prevent disease, contamination and unsanitary conditions; and 
c.  Delineating and describing areas that could be inundated by floods so as to protect individuals from purchasing floodplain lands for purposes which are not in fact suitable. 
(3)  Protecting the public from the burden of extraordinary financial expenditures for flood control and relief, by regulating all uses within the floodplain overlay district so as to produce a method of construction and a pattern of development which will minimize the probability of damage to property and loss of life or injury to the inhabitants of the flood hazard areas. 
(4)  Protecting the storage capacity of floodplains and to assure retention of sufficient floodway area to convey flood flows which can reasonably be expected to occur by: 
a.  Regulating the filling, dumping, dredging or altering of channels through deepening, widening or relocating; 
b.  Prohibiting unnecessary encroachments; and 
c.  Encouraging uses such as open space, parks, recreation and parking. 
(5)  Protecting the hydraulic characteristics of small watercourses, including gulches, sloughs and artificial water channels, which make up a portion of the urban major drainage system, and are used for conveying floodwaters by: 
a.  Regulating filling, dumping and channelization so as to maintain natural storage capacity and slow flow characteristics of watercourses; and 
b.  Prohibiting encroachment into the watercourses. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009) 
Sec. 56-382. - General provisions. 
(a)  The jurisdiction of this section includes all lands adjacent to any water course within the city that would be inundated by the one-hundred-year flood as defined by this floodplain overlay district. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall be interpreted to be minimum requirements and shall be liberally construed in favor of the governing body and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other powers of the city granted by Colorado law. 
(c)  The degree of flood protection required by this floodplain overlay district is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering considerations. On rare occasions greater floods can and will occur and flood heights may be increased by man-made or natural causes. This article does not imply that land outside the floodplain overlay district boundaries, or land uses permitted within such areas, will be free from flooding or flood damages. This article shall not create liability on the part of the community or any official or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on this article or any administrative decision lawfully made thereunder. 
(d)  Boundary map. 
(1)  This floodplain overlay district shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard within the jurisdiction of the city and areas removed from the floodplain by the issuance of a Federal Emergency Management Associations (FEMA) Letter of Map Revision Based On Fill (LOMR-F). 
(2)  No structure or land within the area of special flood hazard shall hereafter be constructed, extended, converted, or altered without full compliance with the terms of this floodplain overlay district and other applicable regulations. 
(3)  The floodplain overlay district is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing easement, covenants, or deed restrictions. Where there is a conflict or overlap between this floodplain overlay district and other zoning district, easement, covenant, or deed restrictions, however, the district with the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009; Ord. No. 14-2010,  1, 12-8-2010; Ord. No. 18-2010,  1, 12-15-2010; Ord. No. 5-2013,  1, 10-23-2013) 
Sec. 56-383. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined below or in other applicable laws, rules or regulations, words or phrases used in this article shall be interpreted to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this article its most reasonable application. 
    Appeal means the request for a review of the city's interpretation of any provisions of this floodplain overlay district or a request for a variance. 
    Area of special flood hazard means the land in the floodplain within a community subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. 
(1)  An "AO zone" means an area of special flood hazard having shallow water depths and/or unpredictable flow paths between one and three feet; and 
(2)  An "AH zone" means an area of special flood hazard having shallow water depths and/or unpredictable flow paths between one and three feet, and with water surface elevations determined. 
    Base flood means the "one-hundred-year flood" and "intermediate regional flood" and means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
    Base flood elevation (BFE) means the elevation shown on a FEMA Flood Insurance Rate Map for Zones AE, AH, A1-A30, AR/A, AR/AE, AR/A1-A30, AR/AH, AR/AO, V1-V30, and FE, that indicates the water surface elevation resulting from a flood that has a one percent chance of equaling or exceeding that level in any given year. 
    Basement means any area of a building having its floor sub-grade (below ground level) on all sides. 
    Conditional letter of map revision (CLOMR) means FEMA's comment on a proposed project, which does not revise an effective floodplain map, that would, upon construction, affect the hydrologic or hydraulic characteristics of a flooding source and thus result in the modification of the existing regulatory floodplain. 
    Critical facility means a structure or related infrastructure, but not the land on which it is situated, as specified in section 56-389.2 herein, that if flooded may result in significant hazards to the public health and safety or interrupt essential services and operations for the city at any time before, during, and after a flood. 
    Development means any man-made change in improved and unimproved real estate, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations or storage of equipment or materials. 
    Flood or flooding means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from: 
(1)  The overflow of inland waters; and/or 
(2)  The unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Flood insurance rate map or FIRM means the official map on which the Federal Emergency Management Agency has delineated both the areas of special flood hazards and the risk premium zones applicable to the city. 
    Flood insurance study means the official report provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency that includes flood profiles, the flood boundary-floodway map, and the water surface elevation of the base flood. 
    Flood proofing means any combination of structural and non-structural additions, changes, or adjustments to structures which reduce or eliminate flood damage to real estate or improved real property, water and sanitary facilities, structures and their contents. 
    Floodplain or flood-prone area means any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source (see definition of flooding). 
    Floodway (regulatory floodway) means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than a designated height. 
    Historic structure means any structure that is: 
(1)  Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places (a listing maintained by the department of interior) or preliminarily determined by the secretary of the interior as meeting the requirements for individual listing on the National Register; 
(2)  Certified or preliminarily determined by the secretary of the interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the secretary to qualify as a registered historic district; 
(3)  Individually listed on a state inventory of historic places in states with historic preservation programs which have been approved by the secretary of the interior; or 
(4)  Individually listed on a local inventory of historic places in communities with historic preservation programs that have been certified either: 
a.  By an approved state program as determined by the secretary of the interior; or 
b.  Directly by the secretary of the interior in states without approved programs. 
    Letter of map revision (LOMR) means FEMA's official revision of an effective flood insurance rate map (FIRM), or flood boundary and floodway map (FBFM), or both. LOMRs are generally based on the implementation of physical measures that affect the hydrologic or hydraulic characteristics of a flooding source and thus result in the modification of the existing regulatory floodway, the effective base flood elevations (BFEs), or the special flood hazard area (SFHA). 
    Letter of map revision based on fill (LOMR-F) means FEMA's modification of the special flood hazard area (SFHA) shown on the flood insurance rate map (FIRM) based on the placement of fill outside the existing regulatory floodway. 
    Lowest floor means the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including basement). An unfinished or flood resistant enclosure, usable solely for parking of vehicles, building access or storage, in an area other than a basement area, is not considered a building's lowest floor, provided that such enclosure is not built in violation of the applicable non-elevation design requirements of this floodplain overlay district. 
    Manufactured home. See section 56-3 of this chapter. 
    Manufactured home park or subdivision . See section 56-3 of this chapter. 
    Mean sea level. For purposes of the National Flood Insurance Program, the National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD) of 1929, or other datum to which base flood elevations shown on a community's flood insurance rate map are referenced. 
    New construction means any building or structure for which the "start of construction" commenced on or after the effective date of this floodplain overlay district. 
    One-hundred-year flood means the "base flood" and "intermediate regional flood," and means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceed in any given year. 
    Recreational vehicle means a vehicle which is: 
(1)  Built on a single chassis; 
(2)  Four hundred square feet or less when measured at the largest horizontal projections; 
(3)  Designed to be self-propelled or permanently towable by a light duty truck; and 
(4)  Designed primarily not for use as a permanent dwelling but as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use. 
    Regulatory flood protection elevation means the elevation equal to the base flood plus one foot. 
    Remedy a violation means to bring the structure or other development into compliance with state or local floodplain management regulations, or, if this is not possible, to reduce the impacts of its noncompliance. Impacts may be reduced by protecting the structure or other affected development from flood damages, implementing the enforcement provisions of this floodplain overlay district or otherwise deterring future similar violations, or reducing federal financial exposure with regard to the structure or other development. 
    Start of construction (for other than new construction or substantial improvements under the Coastal Barrier Resources Act (Pub. L. 97-348)), includes substantial improvement and means the date the building permit was issued, provided the actual start of construction, repair, reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition, placement, or other improvement was within 180 days of the permit date. The actual start means either the first placement of permanent construction of a structure on a site, such as the pouring of slab or footings; the installation of piles; the construction of columns; or any work beyond the state of excavation; or the placement of a manufactured home on a foundation. Permanent construction does not include land preparation, such as clearing, grading or filling; nor does it include the installation of streets and/or walkways, nor does it include excavation for basement, footings, piers or foundations, or the erection of temporary forms, nor does it include the installation on the property of accessory buildings, such as garages or sheds not occupied as dwelling units or not part of the main structure. For a substantial improvement, the actual start of construction means the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of a building, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the building. 
    Structure means a walled and roofed building, including a gas or liquid storage tank that is principally above ground, as well as a manufactured home. 
    Substantial improvement means any reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition, or other improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds 50 percent of the market value of the structure before "start of construction" of the improvement. This includes structures which have incurred "substantial damage," regardless of the actual repair work performed. The term does not, however, include either: 
(1)  Any project for improvement of a structure to correct existing violations of state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which have been identified by the local code enforcement official and which are the minimum necessary conditions; or 
(2)  Any alteration of a "historic structure" provided that the alteration will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a "historic structure." 
    Variance means a grant of relief from the requirement of this floodplain overlay district which permits construction in a manner that would otherwise be prohibited by this district. 
    Violation means the failure of a structure or other development to be fully compliant with the city's floodplain management regulations. A structure or other development without the elevation certificate, other certifications, or other evidence of required compliance is presumed to be in violation until such time as that documentation is provided. 
    Watercourse means a natural or artificial channel of perceptible length and with a definite bed and banks which confines and conducts continuously or intermittently flowing water. 
    Water surface elevation means the height, in relation to the National Geodetic Datum (NGVD) of 1929, (or other datum, where specified) of floods of various magnitudes and frequencies in the floodplains of coastal or riverine areas. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009; Ord. No. 14-2010,  2, 12-8-2010; Ord. No. 5-2013,  2, 10-23-2013) 
Sec. 56-384. - Administration. 
(a)  The zoning administrator is hereby appointed to administer and implement the provisions of this floodplain overlay district by granting or denying development permit applications in accordance with its provisions. 
(b)  A development permit shall be obtained before construction or development begins within any area of special flood hazard identified in the flood insurance study for the city and the flood insurance rate map. Application for a development permit shall be made on forms furnished by the building department and must include, but is not limited to: plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the nature, location, dimensions, and elevations of the area in question; existing or proposed structures, fill, storage of materials, drainage facilities; and the location of the foregoing. In addition, the following information is required: 
(1)  That all necessary permits have been obtained from the federal, state, or local governmental agencies from which prior approval is required; 
(2)  Certification by a registered professional engineer or architect that the floodproofing methods for any nonresidential structure meet the floodproofing criteria in section 56-387 of this chapter; and 
(3)  Description of the extent to which any watercourse will be altered or relocated as a result of proposed development. 
(c)  The zoning administrator shall review all development permits to determine if the proposed development is located in the floodway. If located in the floodway, the zoning administrator shall assure that the proposed development satisfies the encroachment provisions of this article. Approval or denial of a development permit by the zoning administrator shall, in addition to the requirements of this article, be based upon the following relevant factors: 
(1)  The danger to life and property due to the flooding or erosion damage; 
(2)  The susceptibility of the proposed facility and its contents to flood damage and the effect of such damage on the individual owner; 
(3)  The danger that materials may be swept onto other lands to the injury of others; 
(4)  The compatibility of the proposed use with existing and anticipated development; 
(5)  The safety of access to the property in times of flood for ordinary and emergency vehicles; 
(6)  The costs of providing governmental services during and after flood conditions, including maintenance and repair of streets and bridges, and public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems; 
(7)  The expected heights, velocity, duration, rate of rise and sediment transport of the flood waters and the effects of wave action, if applicable, expected at the site; 
(8)  The necessity to the facility of a waterfront location, where applicable; 
(9)  The availability of alternative locations, not subject to flooding or erosion damage, for the proposed use; 
(10)  The relationship of the proposed use to the comprehensive plan for that area. 
(d)  When base flood elevation data has not been provided in the application for a development permit the building official shall obtain, review, and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation data and floodway data available from a federal, state, or other source, as criteria for administering and implementing this floodplain overlay district for new construction, substantial improvements or other development in zone A, as identified on the flood insurance rate map. 
(e)  The zoning administrator shall: 
(1)  Obtain and record the actual elevation (in relation to mean sea level) of the lowest floor (including basement) of all new or substantially improved structures. 
(2)  For all new or substantially improved floodproofed structures: 
a.  Verify and record the actual elevation in relation to mean sea level to which the structure has been floodproofed; and 
b.  Maintain the floodproofing certifications required in this article. 
(3)  Maintain for public inspection all records pertaining to the provisions of this floodplain overlay district, except for those records maintained by the city clerk. 
(4)  Notify adjacent communities, the Colorado Water Conservation Board and the Urban Drainage and Flood Control District prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse, and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
(5)  Require that maintenance is provided within the altered or relocated portion of said watercourse so that the flood-carrying capacity is not diminished. 
(6)  Administer and implement appropriate sections of 44 Code of Federal Regulations ("CFR") (National Flood Insurance Program Regulations) pertaining to floodplain management. 
(f)  Mapping disputes . The zoning administrator shall make interpretations, where needed, as to the exact location of the boundaries of the areas of special flood hazards. The board of adjustment shall decide cases in which a boundary is disputed as provided by this floodplain overlay district. The final decision of the board of adjustment shall be subject to review by certiorari in the manner provided by C.R.S.  31-23-307(1), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009; Ord. No. 14-2010,  3, 4, 12-8-2010) 
Sec. 56-385. - Uses permitted in the flood hazard area. 
    No person shall use land in a floodplain except for the following: 
(a)  Farming, outdoor plant nurseries, wild crop harvesting, but not including the planting and growing of nursery stock whether temporary or permanent in rows, clumps, clusters, or in any manner that would restrict the passage of water as set forth in this article; 
(b)  Private and public recreation uses which do not require structures; 
(c)  Open area uses within residential districts, such as, by way of illustration only, open space, parks and gardens, which do not require structures or plants that will restrict the passage of water; 
(d)  Railroads, streets, bridges, utility lines and facilities, flood control and drainage structures; provided, that such uses are designed in accordance with this floodplain overlay district and designed to cause minimal increases in flood elevation and that such facilities whose failure or interruption would disrupt or endanger the public health, safety or welfare are protected by regulatory flood protection elevation, and also provided that the use has first been approved in writing by the city council; 
(e)  Water distribution and sewage collection facilities and ancillary facilities, including wells and septic tanks, provided that such facilities are designed to employ the best available technology to minimize or prevent infiltration of the facility by floodwaters; 
(f)  Water and sewage treatment facilities and solid waste disposal facilities, provided that such facilities are designed to employ the best available technology to minimize or eliminate infiltration of the facility by flood waters and infiltration of floodwaters by discharge from the facility, and further provided that, in the case of new construction, addition to or modification of existing facilities, emergency plans for action in time of flood, including measures to prevent introduction of any pollutant or toxic material into floodwaters, have been prepared, filed with and approved by any federal, state or local agencies with jurisdiction over such facilities, and also provided that the proposed facility has first been approved in writing by the city council; 
(g)  Parking lots accessory to permitted uses, provided that a warning of potential flood hazard is posted at all times in any parking lot in which flood depths over one-half foot or flood velocities exceeding three feet per second would occur in a one-hundred-year frequency flood; 
(h)  The structural addition or enlargement of any nonconforming structure subject to the following: 
(1)  No such use shall be expanded or enlarged into the flood hazard area except in conformity with the provisions of this floodplain overlay district. 
(2)  Such structures shall be located in relationship to existing structures so as to have no effect upon or obstruction of the flow of water pursuant to its actual or projected route of flow. 
(3)  If such nonconforming use is discontinued, any future use of the building and premises shall conform to the provisions of this floodplain overlay district. 
(4)  Any uses or adjuncts thereof which are nuisances, as prescribed by the Code or state law, shall not be permitted to continue as nonconforming uses. 
(5)  Any alteration or repair to any nonconforming nonresidential structure shall be protected by floodproofing measures as contained in this article. 
(i)  The following are only permitted in an area of special flood hazard as designated on the boundary map described in this article: 
(1)  Residential new construction, or substantial improvements or additions thereto, provided that the lowest floor including basement is located at or above the regulatory flood protection elevation; 
(2)  Commercial, manufacturing, industrial, detached buildings accessory to residential buildings, and other similar structures or any substantial improvements or additions thereto, provided that: 
a.  The lowest floor is located at an elevation equal to or above the regulatory flood protection elevation; or 
b.  The structure is floodproofed to an elevation equal to or above the regulatory flood protection elevation and special circumstances exist which, in the opinion of the building official, make compliance with this section impractical. 
(3)  Alteration, addition or repair to an existing structure that changes its structural integrity, but is less extent than substantial improvement, provided such changes are protected, where possible, by floodproofing measures; 
(4)  Earth fills or deposits of soil materials may be permitted, provided such fills or deposits are adequately protected against erosion by the use of riprap, vegetative cover or other suitable means; 
(5)  All residential and nonresidential structures located within areas of special flood hazard designated as AO or AH zones shall: 
a.  Have the lowest floor, including the basement, elevated above the highest adjacent grade or at least one foot above the depth number specified in feet on the FIRM (at least three feet if no depth number is specified); 
b.  Provide drainage paths around structures on slopes to guide flood waters around and away from those structures; or 
c.  For nonresidential structures, be floodproofed consistent with this article. 
(j)  Other uses similar in nature to permitted uses may be allowed provided that they are consistent with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009; Ord. No. 5-2013,  3, 10-23-2013) 
Sec. 56-386. - Construction and design requirements for new construction, substantial improvements and manufactured homes. 
(a)  New construction and substantial improvements shall be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage. 
(b)  New construction and substantial improvements shall be constructed using methods and practices that minimize flood damage. 
(c)  New construction and substantial improvements to existing structures shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure and to withstand hydrodynamic loads. 
(d)  New construction and substantial improvement of any commercial, industrial or other nonresidential structure shall require that the lowest floor, including the basement and the utility and sanitary facilities of the structure, to be: 
(1)  Floodproofed up to or above the base flood level to make the structure watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water; 
(2)  Built with structural components capable of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effects of buoyancy; 
(3)  Certified by a registered professional engineer or architect that the floodproofing and structural components employed satisfy the standards of this subsection. Such certifications shall be provided to the building official as set forth in this article; and 
(4)  For new construction and substantial improvements occurring in areas of special flood hazard, comply with the provisions of this article. 
(e)  New and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the system. 
(1)  New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the systems and discharge from the systems into flood waters. 
(2)  On-site waste disposal systems shall be located to avoid impairment to them, or contamination from them, during flooding. 
(f)  Electrical, heating, ventilation, plumbing and air-conditioning equipment and other service facilities shall be designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding. 
(g)  Subdivision proposals shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage. 
(1)  Subdivision proposals shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical, and water systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage. 
(2)  Subdivision proposals shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood damage. 
(h)  Base flood elevation data shall be provided for subdivision proposals and other proposed development which contain at least 50 lots or five acres (whichever is smaller in size). 
(i)  New or replacement manufactured homes, and units substantially improved due to flood or fire damage repair, placed within existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions after the effective date of this floodplain overlay district, shall be anchored to resist flotation, collapse, or lateral movement by providing over-the-top or frame ties as specified below or by other measures verified by a document or plan certified by a registered professional engineer to meet or exceed the anchorage requirement as follows: 
(1)  Manufactured homes less than 50 feet in length: 
a.  Over-the-top ties: Four per side (one at each of the four corners plus one additional tie per side); or 
b.  Frame ties: Six per side (one at each corner plus four additional ties per side). 
(2)  Manufactured homes greater than 50 feet in length: 
a.  Over-the-top ties: Four per side (one at each of the four corners plus two additional ties at intermediate locations); or 
b.  Frame ties: Seven per side (one at each corner plus five additional ties per side at intermediate locations). 
(3)  All components of the anchoring system shall be capable of carrying a force of 4,800 pounds, and manufacturer's specifications of the components to be used in the anchoring system shall be submitted to the zoning administrator to demonstrate compliance with this requirement. 
(4)  Any structural additions to the manufactured home shall be similarly anchored. 
(j)  New or substantially improved manufactured homes within manufactured home parks or subdivisions constructed after the effective date of this floodplain overlay district shall be elevated on a permanent foundation such that the lowest floor of the manufactured home is at least one foot above the base flood elevation and is anchored in accordance with this article. 
(k)  For those areas lying within the area of special flood hazard which are also designated as floodways, because of the potential for high velocity flood waters, the potential for debris carried by such flood waters becoming dangerous projectiles, and the potential for substantial erosion, no uses will be permitted therein unless the provisions of this article are satisfied. 
(l)  Recreational vehicles. Recreational vehicles may be parked within the floodplain overlay district subject to the following regulations; either: 
(1)  Recreational vehicles shall be permitted to be parked within the district for a period of less than 180 consecutive days; 
(2)  All recreational vehicles parked within the district shall be fully and currently licensed and capable of being operated on the streets and highways of the State of Colorado; or 
(3)  All recreational vehicles parked within the district shall, when not in use ("not in use" being defined as stored longer than 180 days), be subject to the anchoring provisions of this article and shall meet the elevation requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009; Ord. No. 5-2013,  4, 10-23-2013) 
Sec. 56-387. - Certification of floodproofing measures. 
    New construction and substantial improvements will require the following minimum floodproofing measures verified by a plan or document certified by a registered professional engineer: 
(a)  Anchorage to resist flotation and lateral movement; 
(b)  Installation of watertight doors, bulkheads and shutters in the portion of the structure below the regulatory flood protection elevation; 
(c)  Reinforcement of walls to resist water pressures; 
(d)  Use of paints, membranes or mortars to reduce seepage of water through those portions of the walls below the regulatory flood protection elevation; 
(e)  Addition of mass or weight to structures to resist flotation; 
(f)  Installation of pumps to lower water levels in structures; 
(g)  Construction of water supply and waste collection and treatment systems to prevent entrance of floodwaters; 
(h)  Pumping facilities for subsurface drainage systems for buildings to relieve external foundation wall and basement floor pressures; 
(i)  Construction to resist rupture or collapse, caused by water pressure or floating debris; 
(j)  Cutoff valves on sewer lines or the elimination of gravity flow basement drains; 
(k)  Measures that must be taken which, based upon acceptable engineering standards, insure that construction does not cause the one-hundred-year frequency flood to become more damaging. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009) 
Sec. 56-388. - Certificate of compliance. 
(a)  No vacant land shall be occupied or used, and no building shall be hereafter erected, altered, or moved on the floodplains of any watercourse, nor shall such buildings be occupied until a certificate of compliance shall have been issued by the zoning administrator. 
(b)  The applicant shall submit to the zoning administrator certification from a registered professional engineer that the finished fill and building floor elevations, floodproofing measures, or other protection factors were accomplished in compliance with the provisions of this article. This certification shall also state whether or not the structure contains a basement. Within ten days after receipt of such certification from the applicant, the building official shall issue a certificate of compliance only if the building or premises and the proposed use thereof, conform with all of the requirements of this floodplain overlay district, and shall maintain a permanent record thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009) 
Sec. 56-389. - Uses prohibited in the floodway. 
(a)  The following uses are specifically prohibited in the floodway: 
(1)  Encroachments, including fill, new construction, substantial improvements, or other development that would result in any increase in flood levels during the occurrence of the base flood discharge unless a registered professional engineer certifies and demonstrates to the satisfaction of the zoning administrator that such encroachment will not result in any increase in flood levels; 
(2)  The storage or processing of materials that in time of flooding are buoyant, flammable, explosive, or otherwise potentially injurious to human, animal or plant life and/or property, except these storage prohibitions shall not apply to small items or materials usually used for domestic and household purposes, if applicable; 
(3)  The dumping, storage, or disposal of garbage or other solid waste materials, except such small items necessarily related to domestic and household uses, if applicable; 
(4)  Buildings and structures for human occupancy, being either fixed or mobile; 
(5)  Storage or processing of solid debris that is capable of being carried downstream by floodwaters; 
(6)  Any obstruction which will cause any increase in the base flood elevation of a designated floodway so as to cause foreseeable damage to others, wherever located, as determined by the zoning administrator; 
(7)  For waterways with base flood elevations for which a regulatory floodway has not been designated, no new construction, substantial improvements, or other development (including fill) shall be permitted within zones A1-30 and AE on the city's FIRM, unless it is demonstrated that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one-half foot at any point within the city; 
(8)  Under the provisions of 44 Code of Federal Regulations, Chapter 1, Section 65.12, of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations, a city may approve certain development in zones A1-30, AE, AH, on the city's FIRM which increases the water surface elevation of the base flood by more than one-half foot, provided that the city first applies for a conditional FIRM revision through FEMA (conditional letter of map revision), fulfills the requirements for such revisions as established under the provisions of 44 Code of Federal Regulations, Chapter 1, Section 65.12 and receives FEMA approval. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provisions hereof, no new development within a flood hazard area shall be allowed, nor shall any building or temporary, special or permitted use permit be issued for any use which would: 
(1)  Cause any obstruction which would adversely and substantially affect the efficiency or capacity of any drain way or watercourse; 
(2)  Cause an increase of more than one-half foot in the flood profile elevation in any flood hazard area; 
(3)  Result in storage or processing of flammable, explosive or otherwise potentially injurious materials to human, animal, or plant life and/or property within a flood hazard area, except this storage prohibition shall not apply to small items or materials used for domestic or household purposes; or 
(4)  Result in the construction within a flood hazard area of any structure except those structures which are: 
a.  Designed to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement; 
b.  Which employ materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage; and 
c.  Which employ methods of construction which reduce the danger of flood damage. 
(Ord. No. 1-2009,  1, 3-25-2009; Ord. No. 5-2013,  5, 10-23-2013) 
Sec. 56-389.1. - Properties removed from the floodplain by fill. 
(a)  For waterways with base flood elevations for which a regulatory floodway has not been designated, no new construction, substantial improvements, or other development (including fill) shall be permitted within zones A1-30 and AE on the city's FIRM, unless it is demonstrated that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one-half foot at any point within the city. 
(b)  Under the provisions of 44 Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 1, Section 65.12, of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations, a city may approve certain development in zones A1-30, AE, AH, on the city's FIRM which increases the water surface elevation of the base flood by more than one-half foot, provided that the city first applies for a conditional FIRM revision through FEMA (conditional letter of map revision), fulfills the requirements for such revisions as established under the provisions of 44 Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 1, Section 65.12 and receives FEMA approval. 
(Ord. No. 5-2013,  6, 10-23-2013) 
Sec. 56-389.2. - Standards for critical facilities. 
    A critical facility is a structure or related infrastructure, but not the land on which it is situated, as specified in Rule 6 of the Rules and Regulations for Regulatory Floodplains in Colorado, that if flooded may result in significant hazards to public health and safety or interrupt essential services and operations for the city at any time before, during and after a flood. 
(1)  Classification of critical facilities. It is the responsibility of the city council to identify and confirm that specific structures in their city meet the following criteria: 
Critical facilities are classified under the following categories: (a) essential services; (b) hazardous materials; (c) at-risk populations; and (d) vital to restoring normal services. 
a.  Essential services facilities include public safety, emergency response, emergency medical, designated emergency shelters, communications, public utility plant facilities, and transportation lifelines. 
These facilities consist of: 
1.  Public safety (police stations, fire and rescue stations, emergency vehicle and equipment storage, and, emergency operation centers); 
2.  Emergency medical (hospitals, ambulance service centers, urgent care centers having emergency treatment functions, and non-ambulatory surgical structures but excluding clinics, doctors offices, and non-urgent care medical structures that do not provide these functions); 
3.  Designated emergency shelters; 
4.  Communications (main hubs for telephone, broadcasting equipment for cable systems, satellite dish systems, cellular systems, television, radio, and other emergency warning systems, but excluding towers, poles, lines, cables, and conduits); 
5.  Public utility plant facilities for generation and distribution (hubs, treatment plants, substations and pumping stations for water, power and gas, but not including towers, poles, power lines, buried pipelines, transmission lines, distribution lines, and service lines); and 
6.  Air transportation lifelines (airports (municipal and larger), helicopter pads and structures serving emergency functions, and associated infrastructure (aviation control towers, air traffic control centers, and emergency equipment aircraft hangars). 
Specific exemptions to this category include wastewater treatment plants (WWTP), non-potable water treatment and distribution systems, and hydroelectric power generating plants and related appurtenances. 
Public utility plant facilities may be exempted if it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the city council that the facility is an element of a redundant system for which service will not be interrupted during a flood. At a minimum, it shall be demonstrated that redundant facilities are available (either owned by the same utility or available through an intergovernmental agreement or other contract) and connected, the alternative facilities are either located outside of the 100-year floodplain or are compliant with the provisions of this article, and an operations plan is in effect that states how redundant systems will provide service to the affected area in the event of a flood. Evidence of ongoing redundancy shall be provided to the city council on an as-needed basis upon request. 
b.  Hazardous materials facilities include facilities that produce or store highly volatile, flammable, explosive, toxic and/or water-reactive materials. 
These facilities may include: 
1.  Chemical and pharmaceutical plants (chemical plant, pharmaceutical manufacturing); 
2.  Laboratories containing highly volatile, flammable, explosive, toxic and/or water-reactive materials; 
3.  Refineries; 
4.  Hazardous waste storage and disposal sites; and 
5.  Above ground gasoline or propane storage or sales centers. 
Facilities shall be determined to be critical facilities if they produce or store materials in excess of threshold limits. If the owner of a facility is required by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) to keep a material safety data sheet (MSDS) on file for any chemicals stored or used in the work place, and the chemical(s) is stored in quantities equal to or greater than the threshold planning quantity (TPQ) for that chemical, then that facility shall be considered to be a critical facility. The TPQ for these chemicals is: either 500 pounds or the TPQ listed (whichever is lower) for the 356 chemicals listed under 40 C.F.R.  302 (2010), also known as extremely hazardous substances (EHS); or 10,000 pounds for any other chemical. This threshold is consistent with the requirements for reportable chemicals established by the Colorado Department of Health and Environment. OSHA requirements for MSDS can be found in 29 C.F.R.  1910 (2010). The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulation "Designation, Reportable Quantities, and Notification," 40 C.F.R.  302 (2010) and OSHA regulation "Occupational Safety and Health Standards," 29 C.F.R.  1910 (2010) are incorporated herein by reference and include the regulations in existence at the time of the promulgation of this section, but exclude later amendments to or editions of the regulations Specific exemptions to this category include: 
1.  Finished consumer products within retail centers and households containing hazardous materials intended for household use, and agricultural products intended for agricultural use. 
2.  Buildings and other structures containing hazardous materials for which it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the local authority having jurisdiction by hazard assessment and certification by a qualified professional (as determined by the local jurisdiction having land use authority) that a release of the subject hazardous material does not pose a major threat to the public. 
3.  Pharmaceutical sales, use, storage, and distribution centers that do not manufacture pharmaceutical products. 
These exemptions shall not apply to buildings or other structures that also function as critical facilities under another category outlined in this article. 
c.  At-risk population facilities include medical care, congregate care, and schools. 
These facilities consist of: 
1.  Elder care (nursing homes); 
2.  Congregate care serving 12 or more individuals (day care and assisted living); 
3.  Public and private schools (pre-schools, K-12 schools), before-school and after-school care serving 12 or more children); 
d.  Facilities vital to restoring normal services including government operations. 
These facilities consist of: 
1.  Essential government operations (public records, courts, jails, building permitting and inspection services, city administration and management, maintenance and equipment centers); 
2.  Essential structures for public colleges and universities (dormitories, offices, and classrooms only). 
These facilities may be exempted if it is demonstrated to the city council that the facility is an element of a redundant system for which service will not be interrupted during a flood. At a minimum, it shall be demonstrated that redundant facilities are available (either owned by the same entity or available through an intergovernmental agreement or other contract), the alternative facilities are either located outside of the 100-year floodplain or are compliant with this section, and an operations plan is in effect that states how redundant facilities will provide service to the affected area in the event of a flood. Evidence of ongoing redundancy shall be provided to the city council on an as-needed basis upon request. 
(2)  Protection for critical facilities. All new and substantially improved critical facilities and new additions to critical facilities located within the special flood hazard area shall be regulated to a higher standard than structures not determined to be critical facilities. For the purposes of this section, protection shall include one of the following: 
a.  Location outside the special flood hazard area; or 
b.  Elevation of the lowest floor or floodproofing of the structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, to at least two feet above the base flood elevation. 
(3)  Ingress and egress for new critical facilities . New critical facilities shall, when practicable as determined by the city council, have continuous non-inundated access (ingress and egress for evacuation and emergency services) during a 100-year flood event. 
CERTIFICATION 
    It is hereby found and declared by ___________ (city) that flooding has occurred in the past within its jurisdiction and will certainly occur within the future; that flooding is likely to result in infliction of serious personal injury or death, and is likely to result in substantial injury or destruction of property within its jurisdiction; in order to effectively comply with minimum standards for coverage under the National Flood Insurance Program; and in order to effectively remedy the situation described herein, it is necessary that this ordinance become effective immediately. 
    Therefore, an emergency is hereby declared to exist, and this ordinance, being necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health and safety, shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval.
